This involves graduation from a medical school (usually 4 years), passing an examination, and up to 7 years of 'residency' graduate medical training in occupational medicine. The minimum educational requirement for acceptance to most medical schools is 3 years of college study.

Ophthalmologist (MD).title: Ophthalmologist (MD)
Ophthalmologist (MD).jobTasks:
Ophthalmologists prescribe and treat diseases, injuries and vision problems of patients. Make use of instruments to measure visual acuity, visual deficiencies and eye abnormalties.
They prescribe the corrective lens specifications for eye glasses and contact lens that will correct vision problems. They determine whether contact lenses are appropriate for the patient.
They conduct surgery to remove tumors or foreign substances from the eye. Remove cataracts and correct eye muscle problems. May use laser beams in surgery.
Diagnose the causes of eye infection by observation of patient symptoms and laboratory testing. They prescribe medication and treatments such as heat to kill bacteria and microbes.
Ophthalmologist (MD).earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $119,120 and $300,120 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $380,000.
Ophthalmologist (MD).training: All states require ophthalmologists to be licensed. Licensing involves graduation from a medical school (usually 4 years), passing an examination, and up to 7 years of 'residency' graduate medical training in ophthalmology. The minimum educational requirement for acceptance to most medical schools is 3 years of college study.

Orthodontist (MD).title: Orthodontist (MD)
Orthodontist (MD).jobTasks:
They diagnose the causes of a patient's mouth and dental abnormalities in the jaw, mouth and teeth. Determine whether the abnormalities can be corrected with braces and devices.
May prescribe the removal of teeth or surgery as a preliminary step to the design of braces and devices to realign the patient's teeth or jaw.
They determine for each patient whether orthodontic corrective methods are needed for reasons of the health of teeth, mouth and jaws or for improving appearance.
Design actual braces, wires and other devices needed for each patient. Make adjustments on the devices as patient improves. Design devices patients can insert & remove for long term usage.
Orthodontist (MD).earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $150,060 and $300,120 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $380,000.
Orthodontist (MD).training: All states require orthodontists to be licensed. Licensing requires graduation from an accredited dental school and passing written and practical exams. In addition to completing four years of dental school, most orthodontists have a bachelor's degree from a 4-year college including specialized training. Dental schools require a minimum of two years of pre-dental college training.

Pathologist (MD).title: Pathologist (MD)
Pathologist (MD).jobTasks:
They conduct laboratory tests on tissues and fluids from diseased patients to determine the causes of death and the time and paths taken by diseases, infection, etc.
They trace the progress of a disease in order to determine how a disease can be combatted by physicians in its earliest stages. They recommend diagnostic methods for early disease protection.
They assess and compare the therapeutic value of different medical treatments used to remedy, arrest or cure a disease. They recommend how these treatments are best used.
Perform monitoring studies of patients recovering from diseases to detect symptoms suggesting re-occurrence and they advise what treatments to administer based on samples of tissues and fluids.
Pathologist (MD).earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $119,120 and $300,120 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $380,000.
Pathologist (MD).training: All states require pathologists to be licensed. Licensing involves graduation from a medical school (usually 4 years), passing an examination and up to 7 years of a 'residency' graduate medical training in pathology. The minimum educational requirement for acceptance to most medical schools is three years of college study.

Pediatric Dentist.title: Pediatric Dentist
Pediatric Dentist.jobTasks:
They diagnose patient's problems with teeth and gums for purposes of prevention and correction of diseases, decay, malformations and injuries.
The interpret patient X-rays to diagnose tooth and gum condition and problems. Refer patients for further care to specialists such as oral surgeons and orthodontists as needed.
Aside from the routine preventitive care associated with dentistry, Pediatric Dentists spend a considerable amount of their time educating both the parents and children on oral health care needs, and helping children overcome their fears and accepting health service as a rewarding experience.
Pediatric Dentist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $106,180 and $221,200 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $320,000.
Pediatric Dentist.training: All training programs require successful completion of the Dental Admission Test. All states require dentists to be licensed. Licensing requires graduation from an accredited dental school and passing written and practical exams. In addition to completing four years of dental school, most dentists have a bachelor's degree from a 4-year college.

Pediatrician (MD).title: Pediatrician (MD)
Pediatrician (MD).jobTasks:
Pediatricians perform complete physical examinations of babies at time of birth to identify any immediaate problem needing attention or symptoms suggesting future problems.
They evaluate physical development of children to determine if growth of bones, limbs, head, eyes, etc. are following the expected developmental patterns for children of the same age.
Prescribe diets and vitamins needed based on child's age, and eating or digestive disorders. They prescribe medications & treatments for illnesses. Give vaccinations against diseases.
Assess the child's reflexes, eye/hand coordination, dexterity, physical mobility & sensory abilities to assure normal growth. Prescribe exercises and activities to remedy deficiencies.
Pediatrician (MD).earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $131,850 and $221,200 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $320,000.
Pediatrician (MD).training: All states require pediatricians to be licensed. Licensing involves graduation from a medical school (usually 4 years), passing an examination, and up to 7 years of 'residency' graduate medical training in pediatrics. The minimum educational requirement for acceptance to most medical schools is 3 years of college study.

Plastic Surgeon.title: Plastic Surgeon
Plastic Surgeon.jobTasks: A plastic surgeon deals with the repair, reconstruction, or replacement of physical defects of form or function involving the skin, musculoskeletal system, head and facial structures, hand, extremities, breasts and trunk. A plastic surgeon uses aesthetic surgical principles not only to improve undesirable qualities of normal structures, but in all reconstructive procedures as well.
Plastic Surgeon.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $197,070 and $300,120 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $380,000.
Plastic Surgeon.training: All states require plastic surgeons to be licensed. Licensing involves graduation from a medical school (usually 4 years), passing an examination, and up to 8 years of 'residency'. Residency in plastic surgery consists of three to five years of training in general surgery followed by a two to three year residency in plastic surgery.

Preventive Medicine Physicians.title: Preventive Medicine Physicians
Preventive Medicine Physicians.jobTasks: Direct or manage prevention programs in specialty areas such as aerospace, occupational, infectious disease, and environmental medicine. Identify groups at risk for specific preventable diseases or injuries. Direct public health education programs dealing with topics such as preventable diseases, injuries, nutrition, food service sanitation, water supply safety, sewage and waste disposal, insect control, and immunizations. Supervise or coordinate the work of physicians, nurses, statisticians, or other professional staff members. Evaluate the effectiveness of prescribed risk reduction measures or other interventions. Deliver presentations to lay or professional audiences.
Preventive Medicine Physicians.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $112,210 and $208,000 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $208,000.

Psychiatrist (MD).title: Psychiatrist (MD)
Psychiatrist (MD).jobTasks:
They diagnose and prescribe treatment for patients suffering from emotional and behavioral disorders. Interview, test and observe patients to determine specific type of disorder.
Analyze patient's past history, family, social and work environment to identify psycho-social stresses and physiological factors that contribute to the patient's disorder.
Prescribe medical and behavior modification activities to the patient. They counsel patients to help them gain insight into factors causing their anxieties or disorders.
Meet with patients periodically to assess their progress. May meet with and counsel patient's family members as a means of optimizing the patient's social environment.
Psychiatrist (MD).earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $125,570 and $221,200 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $320,000.
Psychiatrist (MD).training: Training for psychiatrists consists of undergraduate and graduate school with a major in psychology plus graduation from a medical school with specialization in psychiatry. Following medical school, almost all psychiatrists spend five to seven years in a graduate medical education program called a residency. State licensing is required.

Radiologist (MD).title: Radiologist (MD)
Radiologist (MD).jobTasks:
Radiologists examine internal body structures and functions of organ systems and make diagnoses after integrating all information from X-ray findings and laboratory tests.
They test benign and malignant internal and external tumors by exposure to radiations from X-rays or implanting radioisotopes in affected body areas.
They administer substances into patient's body orally, enemas or injection which show up as opaque on X-rays. Use live TV to observe opaque materials in patient's body.
Confer with surgeons to determine need for surgery and the surgical methods which are most appropriate to remove or repair the affected areas.
Radiologist (MD).earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $119,120 and $300,120 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $380,000.
Radiologist (MD).training: All states require radiologists to be licensed. Licensing involves graduation from a medical school (usually 4 years), passing an examination, and up to 7 years of 'residency' graduate medical training in radiology. The minimum educational requirement for acceptance to most medical schools is 3 years of college study.

Sports Medicine Physicians.title: Sports Medicine Physicians
Sports Medicine Physicians.jobTasks: Diagnose or treat disorders of the musculoskeletal system. Order and interpret the results of laboratory tests and diagnostic imaging procedures. Advise against injured athletes returning to games or competition if resuming activity could lead to further injury. Record athletes' medical care information and maintain medical records. Examine and evaluate athletes prior to participation in sports activities to determine level of physical fitness or predisposition to injuries. Coordinate sports care activities with other experts including specialty physicians and surgeons, athletic trainers, physical therapists, or coaches.
Sports Medicine Physicians.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $112,210 and $208,000 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $208,000.

Sports Physician (Orthopedist).title: Sports Physician (Orthopedist)
Sports Physician (Orthopedist).jobTasks:
Sports physicians personally examine and evaluate all candidates for a sport team prior to their participation in games to determine physical fitness. They assess balance, coordination, stamina and strength.
They select and fit all protective gear and equipment for athletes based on in-depth knowledge of kind of injuries that occur in a given sport due to collisions, falls, fatique & muscle sprains.
They diagnose the extent of athletes' injuries by X-ray and examination of athlete's physical condition immediately after the injury. Prescribe treatment and therapy. May perform surgery.
They supervise the team's trainers and coaches in the use of physiotherapeutic techniques in the training room. They prescribe injury rehabilitation exercises for each player.
Sports Physician (Orthopedist).earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 55,720 and $106,170 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $135,650.
Sports Physician (Orthopedist).training: All states require Sports Physicians, who are usually orthopedists, to be licensed. Licensing requires graduation from a medical school (usually four years), passing an examination, and four years of 'residency' graduate medical training in orthopedics. Minimum education for acceptance to most medical schools is three years of college.

Surgeons (MD).title: Surgeons (MD)
Surgeons (MD).jobTasks: Treat diseases, injuries, and deformities by invasive methods, such as manual manipulation or by using instruments and appliances.
Surgeons (MD).earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $197,070 and $300,120 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $380,000.
Surgeons (MD).training: This occupation generally requires an advanced degree (e.g. Ph.D.). The typical commitment is a minimum of 3 years of study beyond a Bachelorâ€™s or Masterâ€™s Degree.

Urologists.title: Urologists
Urologists.jobTasks: Diagnose or treat diseases or disorders of genitourinary organs and tracts including erectile dysfunction (ED), infertility, incontinence, bladder cancer, prostate cancer, urethral stones, or premature ejaculation. Document or review patients' histories. Order and interpret the results of diagnostic tests, such as prostate specific antigen (PSA) screening, to detect prostate cancer. Perform abdominal, pelvic, or retroperitoneal surgeries. Examine patients using equipment, such as radiograph (x-ray) machines or fluoroscopes, to determine the nature and extent of disorder or injury. Treat lower urinary tract dysfunctions using equipment such as diathermy machines, catheters, cystoscopes, or radium emanation tubes.
Urologists.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $112,210 and $208,000 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $208,000.

Art Therapist.title: Art Therapist
Art Therapist.jobTasks:
They educate mentally disturbed patients with skills needed to create paintings, drawings and sculptures as a means for self- expression, releasing of emotions and insight to their problems.
They assess patients' level of functioning to determine what art form(s) would be appropriate for the patient to attempt. They help patients to experiment with techniques and materials.
Jointly review with patients their art work in order to assist them explore their problems. They advise patients about methods to enrich artistic quality and deepen the therapeutic value.
They confer with psychiatric and medical team members responsible for patients in order to receive information about patients' behavior. They use this information to assess treatment methods.
Art Therapist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 35,570 and $ 59,680 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 72,340.
Art Therapist.training: Training is very specialized and must be pursued at a college or university accredited by the American Art Therapy Association. A bachelor's degree is a necessary pre-requisite, a master's is needed for therapeutic practice, and a Ph.D. for college teaching jobs. Art therapy education includes a study of fine arts, psychology and sociology. An additional degree in social work or counseling will enhance your job opportunities.

Athletic Trainer.title: Athletic Trainer
Athletic Trainer.jobTasks:
They evaluate the playing fitness of each team member and decide what kinds of exercises, therapy and diets are needed to optomize the player's condition.
They request medical examinations and diagnoses by physicians when players experience pain or receive injuries.
They administer treatment recommended by physicians for each player. This could include massages, whirlpool, heat treatments and wrappings.
They decide when players should be taken out of games because of an injury and how many games they should skip in order to fully recover from an injury.
Athletic Trainer.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 37,010 and $ 56,320 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 69,140.
Athletic Trainer.training: Employment of athletic trainers is expected to grow much faster than average through 2018 spurred by the increasing number of people, especially retirees, that become involved in recreational sports like tennis and golf.

Clinical Psychologist.title: Clinical Psychologist
Clinical Psychologist.jobTasks:
They diagnose underlying causes for their clients' disorders by interviewing, observing, testing and studying their clients' history. Evaluate client's ability to function in society.
Prescribe treatment needed to help their clients cope with the stresses of their environment. They identify the kind of situations and stimuli that trigger clients' emotional problems.
Confer with psychiatrists to determine if medical drug therapy is warranted. Tney use behavior modification techniques such as role playing, play therapy and positive reinforcement.
They determine what level of psychological assistance is needed by patients. Decide upon the kind of therapy and counseling needed and how to assess the patient's progress over time.
Clinical Psychologist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 55,050 and $ 95,910 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $120,320.
Clinical Psychologist.training: A master's or a doctorate's degree is generally required for employment as a clinical psychologist. To provide counseling services as a practicing psychologist, licensing is required in most states. Licensing often requires a doctorate in psychology, one to two years of work experience, and a written and oral examination.

Clinical Sociologist.title: Clinical Sociologist
Clinical Sociologist.jobTasks:
They diagnose psychological problems and grievances of groups of people who are suffering from social difficulties such as loss of job, discrimination or poverty.
Perform 'needs assessment' studies to determine what kinds of skills or assistance are needed by troubled groups to cope with their problems.
They design counseling and educational training programs to help troubled groups develop social or job skills needed to break out their difficulties. Estimate program costs and requests funds.
They conduct studies to evaluate results of programs designed to help troubled groups. They recommend changes needed to improve program success.
Clinical Sociologist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 57,650 and $108,130 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $146,860.
Clinical Sociologist.training: A master's degree in sociology is usually the minimum requirement for employment in applied research or teaching. A Ph.D. degree is essential for most senior positions in research institutes, government agencies and college faculty positions.

Counseling Psychologist.title: Counseling Psychologist
Counseling Psychologist.jobTasks:
They interview clients, who may be students, married couples or workers, to determine the nature of the adjustment problems they are experiencing.
May administer tests to the client to assess their personal attributes such as abilities, interest, values, personality type and methods of coping with problems.
Help the client identify factors in their social, business and educational background that cause stress, ambiguity or conflict. Suggests ways to the client to cope with problems.
In colleges they provide career planning and job placement services for students and alumni. Help unemployed persons with skills planning in employment service centers.
Counseling Psychologist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 55,050 and $ 95,910 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $120,320.
Counseling Psychologist.training: A master's or a doctorate's degree is generally required for employment as a counseling psychologist. To provide counseling services as a practicing psychologist, licensing is required in most states.

Developmental Psychologist.title: Developmental Psychologist
Developmental Psychologist.jobTasks:
Conduct studies of personal growth and development of persons from infancy to old age by means of observations, surveys and interviews.
They identify patterns and norms for intellectual, emotional, physical and social growh to persons. Identify differences between ages, sexes, races and cultural backgrounds.
They design tests to determine if persons are developing in accordance with the expectations for their age group. Makes comparisons between persons coming from different backgrounds.
Make recommendations to enhance the development of children, adolescents and young adults. Suggestions include nutrition, exercise, education and medical care.
Developmental Psychologist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 55,050 and $ 95,910 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $120,320.
Developmental Psychologist.training: A master's or a doctorate's degree is generally required for employment as a developmental psychologist. To provide counseling services as a practicing psychologist, licensing is required in most states. Licensing often requires a doctorate's degree in psychology, one to two years of work experience and passing a written and oral examination.

Educational Therapist.title: Educational Therapist
Educational Therapist.jobTasks:
They assess students who have emotional and/or neurological handicaps to determine their educational needs. This is done by testing, interviewing and observation.
They teach and give students personal guidance and counseling to help them cope with their disabilities.
They meet with parents to assess their home environment. They advise parents in methods to assist their children with study habits and homework.
They design and implement special teaching aids such as computer-aided instruction, project assignments and field trips.
Educational Therapist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 42,140 and $ 74,390 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 95,530.
Educational Therapist.training: A bachelor's degree in educational therapy is the minimal requirement for entry into this field. A master's degree is desirable. In addition, most states require a license to practice. Educational therapy coursework includes the study of special education for students with learning or emotional disabilities, career counseling, psychology and psychological tests and measurements.

Exercise Physiologist.title: Exercise Physiologist
Exercise Physiologist.jobTasks:
Perform research with athletes to identify human biomechanical principles to enhance athletes' performance, i.e., computer analysis revealed ideal placement of feet for javelin throwing.
They analyze the relationship between athlete's ability to use oxygen & body physiology, nutrition & exercise. Make comparisons between human physique & endurance, agility & muscle strengths.
They can specialize in training and conditioning of women for athletic events that require strength & endurance. Confer with trainers and nutritionists to optimize women's athletic ability.
They consult with trainers of professional olympic athletes to develop customized exercise prescriptions for each athlete depending upon their unique skeletal and muscular structures.
Exercise Physiologist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 38,270 and $ 59,500 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 74,330.
Exercise Physiologist.training: Preparation for this field requires the completion of a master's degree in human physiology and a strong background in physical education and bio-mechanics. A working knowledge of computers will also be helpful. Many exercise physiologists complete their doctorate's degree (Ph.D).

Manual Arts Therapist.title: Manual Arts Therapist
Manual Arts Therapist.jobTasks:
They evaluate recovering patients' motor skills to determine their level of mobility and identify present limitations. Interview patients to identify level of physical activity prior to injury.
They prescribe manual arts activities to exercise muscles, improve perceptual motor skills and manual dexterity.
They train patients to use tools and equipment needed to perform the manual arts tasks. They evaluate the patient's progress and reinforce their efforts with praise and recognition.
Decide what kinds of manual arts to include as a therapeutic activity that can be prescribed to patients. Make choices on the basis of the patient's interest, motivation and therapeutic value.
Manual Arts Therapist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 67,140 and $ 99,300 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $119,720.
Manual Arts Therapist.training: A bachelor's degree in manual arts therapy is the minimal requirement for entry into this field. A master's degree is more desirable. In addition most states require a license to practice. Manual arts therapy coursework includes the study of perceptual and fine motor skills learning and development, occupational therapy, and career counseling psychology.

Marriage and Family Therapists.title: Marriage and Family Therapists
Marriage and Family Therapists.jobTasks: Ask questions that will help clients identify their feelings and behaviors. Counsel clients on concerns, such as unsatisfactory relationships, divorce and separation, child rearing, home management, and financial difficulties. Encourage individuals and family members to develop and use skills and strategies for confronting their problems in a constructive manner. Maintain case files that include activities, progress notes, evaluations, and recommendations. Develop and implement individualized treatment plans addressing family relationship problems, destructive patterns of behavior, and other personal issues. Collect information about clients, using techniques such as testing, interviewing, discussion, and observation. Confer with clients to develop plans for posttreatment activities. Confer with other counselors, doctors, and professionals to analyze individual cases and to coordinate counseling services. Determine whether clients should be counseled or referred to other specialists in such fields as medicine, psychiatry, and legal aid. Follow up on results of counseling programs and clients' adjustments to determine effectiveness of programs.
Marriage and Family Therapists.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 38,320 and $ 63,810 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 81,960.
Marriage and Family Therapists.training: Requires a masters degree. Most states require licensing. Check with your state for specific requirements,

Massage Therapist.title: Massage Therapist
Massage Therapist.jobTasks:
They manually manipulate a patient's body tissues for the purpose of restoring the functions of muscles and joints, improving circulation and relieving physical fatigue and stress.
Massage therapy includes the use of hydrotherapy (whirlpools), heat and exercise to assist in the rehabilitation process and recovery from sprains, fractures and dislocations.
By improving circulation, they reduce convalescent periods after surgery. Their techniques also help eliminate pain from neural, arthritic and rheumatic conditions.
They apply massage to relieve various forms of paralysis, insomnia and migraine headaches caused by nervous system disorders. Some specialize in treatment of sports injuries.
Massage Therapist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 27,230 and $ 57,120 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 74,870.
Massage Therapist.training: Programs approved by the American Massage Therapy Association are offered by technical institutes and massage therapy institutes and colleges across the USA. Length of training ranges from six to twelve months and leads to a diploma. Course work and internships cover the areas of anatomy and physiology, neurology, hydrotherapy, hygiene, and massage techniques. Most states require licensing examinations.

Mental Health Counselor.title: Mental Health Counselor
Mental Health Counselor.jobTasks: Maintain confidentiality of records relating to clients' treatment. Assess patients for risk of suicide attempts. Encourage clients to express their feelings and discuss what is happening in their lives, helping them to develop insight into themselves or their relationships. Collect information about clients through interviews, observation, or tests. Counsel clients or patients, individually or in group sessions, to assist in overcoming dependencies, adjusting to life, or making changes. Guide clients in the development of skills or strategies for dealing with their problems. Develop and implement treatment plans based on clinical experience and knowledge. Fill out and maintain client-related paperwork, including federal- and state-mandated forms, client diagnostic records, and progress notes. Prepare and maintain all required treatment records and reports. Evaluate clients' physical or mental condition, based on review of client information.
Mental Health Counselor.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 33,560 and $ 55,440 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 70,100.
Mental Health Counselor.training: Requires a Masters Degree and licensing.

Occupational Therapist.title: Occupational Therapist
Occupational Therapist.jobTasks:
They assess the physical, mental or emotional deficiencies of patients. Prescribe exercises and training activities to help restore lost skills and develop new ones.
Interview patients to understand their past and present occupational and career history. Counsel the patient about the potential impact of their handicaps on their work performance.
They advise employers how these patients can fulfill prior job duties in an organization by re-designing job methods, work stations and job tools and equipment.
Train patients in skills that will help them cope with permanent disabilities. They design aids for their place of employment and home enabling them to remain independent.
Occupational Therapist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 67,140 and $ 99,300 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $119,720.
Occupational Therapist.training: A master's degree in occupational therapy is the minimum requirement for entry in this field. Most states require a license that is obtained by having an occupational therapy degree and passing an examination.

Physical Therapist.title: Physical Therapist
Physical Therapist.jobTasks:
They evaluate patients' needs by referring to medical doctor's recommendations and by examination of the patient's physical abilities and present limitations.
Examine the limbs, joints or areas which have been injured or where the patient is experiencing pain. They massage and manipulate muscles and joints to restore mobility.
They administer treatments to injured areas through the use of whirlpool baths, heat and ultrasound equipment. Prescribe and administer exercises on electro-mechanical exercise equipment.
They increase patients range of joint movement through the use of power equipment that automatically moves the patients' limbs. Prescribe long term exercises for self-maintenance of health.
Physical Therapist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 70,680 and $100,880 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $122,130.
Physical Therapist.training: All states require physical therapists to pass a licensing examination after graduating from an accredited physical therapy program with either a bachelor's degree or a master's degree. A master's degree is required for research and teaching positions.

Recreational Therapist.title: Recreational Therapist
Recreational Therapist.jobTasks:
They receive instructions from patients' physicians and psychologists suggesting what kinds of recreation will be most helpful for a patient.
They plan activities such as manual crafts, sculpting and social activities such as dancing and singing for individual patients or as a group activity.
They instruct the patients during the recreational activities and observes how receptive they are and what physical or emotional benefits they receive from the activities.
Prepare reports describing each patient's progress and response to recreational therapy. Meet with the medical team to review the patient's progress and future activities.
Recreational Therapist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 35,570 and $ 59,680 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 72,340.
Recreational Therapist.training: A college degree in therapeutic recreation is the usual requirement for a hospital or clinic position. An associate degree with qualifying work experience is sufficient for recreational activity director positions in nursing homes, while a bachelor's is preferred by hospitals.

Speech Pathologist.title: Speech Pathologist
Speech Pathologist.jobTasks:
They specialize in diagnoses and treatment of speech and language problems and conduct studies to determine the causes and methods to treat speech communication problems.
They assess individual patients to determine how speech, voice and language disorders are related to educational, medical, social and psychological factors.
They provide individual counseling and guidance to speech and language disabled persons. Act as a consultant to educators of persons with speech disorders.
Conduct research studies to determine the role of physiological, sociological and psychological variables as a cause of speech and language disorders. They evaluate remedial techniques.
Speech Pathologist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 58,480 and $ 95,000 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $116,810.
Speech Pathologist.training: Almost all states require that speech pathologists be licensed To be licensed, one needs a master's degree in speech pathology, 375 hours of supervised clinical experience, pass a national examination plus nine months of post graduate professional experience. In some states, those with a bachelor's degree in speech-language pathology may work in schools with students who have communication problems.

Speech-Language Pathology Assistants.title: Speech-Language Pathology Assistants
Speech-Language Pathology Assistants.jobTasks: Implement treatment plans or protocols as directed by speech-language pathologists. Document clients' progress toward meeting established treatment objectives. Assist speech-language pathologists in the remediation or development of speech and language skills. Perform support duties, such as preparing materials, keeping records, maintaining supplies, and scheduling activities. Collect and compile data to document clients' performance or assess program quality.
Speech-Language Pathology Assistants.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 29,460 and $ 48,440 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 58,500.

Vocational Rehabilitation Counselor.title: Vocational Rehabilitation Counselor
Vocational Rehabilitation Counselor.jobTasks:
They interview and evaluate handicapped persons to determine in what ways their handicap limits their work performance and they assess their work related skills and abilities.
Perform an overall assessment of their client's interests, values, goals, education and past work experience. They identify occupations and jobs compatible with the person's attributes.
Counsel the handicapped client and help them explore job and occupational alternatives for which the person could qualify. They arrange for training needed by the person.
Work with government agencies and business organizations for the purpose of placing the clients in jobs. They perform follow-up studies to evaluate their clients' on the job success.
Vocational Rehabilitation Counselor.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 26,860 and $ 46,600 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 62,010.
Vocational Rehabilitation Counselor.training: Generally, vocational rehabilitation counselors must have a master's degree in rehabilitation counseling and additional studies in mental health counseling, career counseling, counseling psychology and human resource management. In most states, certification is required.

Anesthesiologist Assistants.title: Anesthesiologist Assistants
Anesthesiologist Assistants.jobTasks: Provide airway management interventions including tracheal intubation, fiber optics, or ventilary support. Respond to emergency situations by providing cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), basic cardiac life support (BLS), advanced cardiac life support (ACLS), or pediatric advanced life support (PALS). Verify availability of operating room supplies, medications, and gases. Participate in seminars, workshops, or other professional activities to keep abreast of developments in anesthesiology. Assist anesthesiologists in monitoring of patients, including electrocardiogram (EKG), direct arterial pressure, central venous pressure, arterial blood gas, hematocrit, or routine measurement of temperature, respiration, blood pressure or heart rate. Assist in the provision of advanced life support techniques including those procedures using high frequency ventilation or intra-arterial cardiovascular assistance devices.
Anesthesiologist Assistants.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 92,800 and $130,530 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $157,120.

Cardiovascular Technologist.title: Cardiovascular Technologist
Cardiovascular Technologist.jobTasks:
They administer tests and treatments to patients suffering heart, lung or blood disorders. Evaluate results and reports patient's progress to the physician.
They train patients to use equipment that enables them to get optimum benefits from treatments.
They evaluate, purchase and arrange for installment of medical equipment from manufacturers. Test the accuracy of equipment and arrange for training of users.
Advise physicians about their observations regarding the ease of use of the equipment and the apparent success or usefulness of the equipment.
Cardiovascular Technologist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 37,690 and $ 73,050 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 89,450.
Cardiovascular Technologist.training: A two-year college associate degree in cardiopulmonary technology is the usual educational preparation for this field. Voluntary professional certification is useful and can be obtained through appropriate cardiological associations.

EEG Technician/Technologist.title: EEG Technician/Technologist
EEG Technician/Technologist.jobTasks:
They use instruments to record electrical impulses transmitted by the brain and the nervous system to help physicians diagnose brain disorders.
They apply electrodes to designated spots on the patient's head and set up instruments to assess the effects of tumors, epilepsy, cerebral injuries and sleep disorders.
They assess the probabability of a patient's recovery from a coma or determine if the patient is cerebrally dead as indicated by the absence of brain activity.
They perform EEG monitoring during surgery in the operating room to assess the effects of anesthesia on the brain. Some specialize in the diagnosis of sleep disorders.
EEG Technician/Technologist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 37,690 and $ 73,050 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 89,450.
EEG Technician/Technologist.training: Training programs are offered in technical institutes that last 12 to 14 months. Some colleges also offer two-year associate degree programs. Training consists of laboratory experience as well as courses in human anatomy, physiology, neurology, computer applications and electronic instrumentation. Certification can be achieved by examination.

Endoscopy Technicians.title: Endoscopy Technicians
Endoscopy Technicians.jobTasks: Clean, disinfect, or calibrate scopes or other endoscopic instruments according to manufacturer recommendations and facility standards. Prepare suites or rooms according to endoscopic procedure requirements. Assist physicians or registered nurses in the conduct of endoscopic procedures. Collect specimens from patients, using standard medical procedures. Maintain or repair endoscopic equipment.
Endoscopy Technicians.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 29,460 and $ 48,440 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 58,500.

Medical Appliance Technician.title: Medical Appliance Technician
Medical Appliance Technician.jobTasks: Fit appliances onto patients and make any necessary adjustments. Make orthotic or prosthetic devices, using materials such as thermoplastic and thermosetting materials, metal alloys and leather, and hand or power tools. Read prescriptions or specifications to determine the type of product or device to be fabricated and the materials and tools that will be required. Repair, modify, or maintain medical supportive devices, such as artificial limbs, braces, or surgical supports, according to specifications. Instruct patients in use of prosthetic or orthotic devices. Take patients' body or limb measurements for use in device construction. Construct or receive casts or impressions of patients' torsos or limbs for use as cutting and fabrication patterns. Bend, form, and shape fabric or material to conform to prescribed contours of structural components. Drill and tap holes for rivets and glue, weld, bolt, or rivet parts together to form prosthetic or orthotic devices. Lay out and mark dimensions of parts, using templates and precision measuring instruments.
Medical Appliance Technician.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 28,310 and $ 46,910 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 62,720.
Medical Appliance Technician.training: Training for this occupation generally requires a High School Degree, plus additional coursework in a vocational or technical school. In some cases, employers may require an Associate Degree.

Medical Assistant.title: Medical Assistant
Medical Assistant.jobTasks:
Clerical duties performed can include answering telephone calls, updating and filing patient records, completing insurance forms, scheduling appointments, and arranging for patient lab tests.
Duties can vary and include taking patients' medical histories, measuring and recording vital signs, explaining treatment procedures and instructing patients about medications and diets.
They may prepare patients for examination, draw blood and assist a physician in a patient examination or treatment. They also perform routine laboratory tests and apply dressings.
They work in all medical specialties such as pediatrics, family practice, orthopedics, etc. Their role is to act as the liaison between the patient and the physician.
Medical Assistant.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 26,860 and $ 37,760 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 45,310.
Medical Assistant.training: Training programs in medical assisting are offered in technical institutes and community colleges. Most programs require 12 to 16 months to receive a certificate and consist of courses in anatomy, physiology, medical laboratory techniques, pharmaceutical principles, medical records, insurance and medical diagnostic procedures. Two-year associate degree programs are also available.

Medical Equipment Technician.title: Medical Equipment Technician
Medical Equipment Technician.jobTasks:
Medical equipment technicians install medical equipment & instruments such as patient monitors, X-ray machines, sterilizers, blood analyzers, etc. in hospitals, physician offices, medical laboratories, etc.
They calibrate new equipment. They demonstrate the most effective methods to use the equipment and how to verify the accuracy of results.
They perform routine tests of the reliability of the biomedical equipment at the customer's site. They diagnose causes of equipment malfunction and performs repairs. They also advise staff of problems.
They advise his/her company's engineering & marketing staff of unusual equipment malfunctions and suggest design changes to improve the reliability of equipment for customer satisfaction.
Medical Equipment Technician.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 36,160 and $ 62,370 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 78,520.
Medical Equipment Technician.training: An associate degree is the usual requirement for this occupation. Curriculum background should include biophysics, physiology, anatomy and computer-aided design. Certification in this field is voluntary.

Medical Laboratory Technician.title: Medical Laboratory Technician
Medical Laboratory Technician.jobTasks:
They analyze the content of body fluids including blood, urine and spinal fluids to detect infectious organisms, cancer, presence of antibodies and to identify blood types.
They use complex precision instruments, computers and chemicals to analyze and measure levels of blood glucose, cholesterol and other blood components.
They confer with medical technologists, physicians and laboratory managers to describe test results to be used in diagnoses and evaluation of the effects of treatments and medications.
They may specialize in areas such as histology dealing with tissues, cytology (body cells) and phlebotomy dealing with blood analysis. They may assist medical laboratory technologists.
Medical Laboratory Technician.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 31,250 and $ 49,920 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 61,720.
Medical Laboratory Technician.training: These technicians must have either a certificate from a technical institute that takes about 14 months to complete or a 2-year college associate degree. The education program focuses on laboratory sciences with an emphasis on chemistry and biology plus clinical laboratory work experience.

Medical Photographer.title: Medical Photographer
Medical Photographer.jobTasks:
They confer with surgeons, physicians, pathologists and medical researchers to identify their photographic needs for reasons of diagnoses or use in publications, educational aids or research.
For each project, decide what types of photographic equipment to use such as microscopic, ultraspeed, infrared, ultraviolet, etc. Work with the medical experts to schedule and set up a project.
They operate the photographic equipment to take photos of surgical procedures, tissue, specimens, bone and muscle structures and the results of cameras exploring the body system.
They edit and enlarge the photos in accordance with the project objectives. Experiment with new technology to enhance quality and access to subjects being photographed.
Medical Photographer.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 23,480 and $ 52,220 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 76,220.
Medical Photographer.training: Entry level positions in medical photography require a college degree at either the bachelor or associate degree level. In addition to studies in photography, it is essential that you take courses in the area of medicine that you wish to concentrate such as surgery, laboratory research, diseases, etc. Applicants should assemble a 'portfolio' of their best photographic works to show prospective employers.

Medical Records Technician.title: Medical Records Technician
Medical Records Technician.jobTasks:
They analyze each patient's medical records in order to classify symptoms, diagnosis and treatments into categories which are used for billing, insurance and making decisions about patient care.
They transmit the patient information to appropriate departments in a hospital or a clinic such as administration, billing, cost accounting, medical library, x-ray, diet, etc.
They use computer software to prepare statistical reports for physicians that tabulate the percent of patients with specific profiles of symptoms, treatment administered and recovery rates.
They prepare bills and reports for insurance companies. They participate in administrative research teams to advise about the clarity and ease of use of the medical coding schemes.
Medical Records Technician.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 29,940 and $ 49,770 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 62,840.
Medical Records Technician.training: Medical record technicians entering the field usually have 4 to 6 months of training in a technical institute or an associate degree from a 2-year Community College. The American Health Information Management Association also offers similar training programs. Most employers prefer to hire accredited record technicians who have passed the necessary examinations.

Medical Secretary.title: Medical Secretary
Medical Secretary.jobTasks:
Prepare and organize reports for physicians regarding patients' diagnoses, laboratory tests and prescribed treatments. They keep records of prescriptions and surgery or procedures performed.
Use computer systems to calculate fees and generate invoices for patients and the documents needed to coordinate a patient's insurance claims. Pay invoices received by the doctor's office.
They type the physician's professional correspondence. Attend medical meetings held by physicians and summarizes the meeting proceedings and conclusions with typed reports.
They assess new computer-based software system for organizing and classifying physician's records and business transactions. They decide which software to purchase.
Medical Secretary.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 27,710 and $ 40,400 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 49,730.
Medical Secretary.training: Physicians' offices, hospitals, medical laboratories and clinics prefer to hire applicants for medical secretary positions who have an associate degree, or equivalent, from a college or a business school. The study program must prepare you to work in the medical field and provide you with computer application skills.

Medical Technologist.title: Medical Technologist
Medical Technologist.jobTasks:
They conduct medical tests on patients' specimens of body fluids and tissues to determine if the specimens contain the accepted level of chemicals, minerals, cells, etc.
They identify the presence of bacteria and parasites that can cause illness and disease. Evaluate the effects of medications and treatments on the growth of bacteria and parasites.
May take repeated specimens from patients to conduct a wide range of medical tests. They may decide to conduct further tests using different types of laboratory test equipment & procedures.
They track individual patients' status by observing trends or shifts in the results of the laboratory tests. They advise physicians about life threatening observations.
Medical Technologist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 51,370 and $ 73,760 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 85,160.
Medical Technologist.training: The usual requirement for an entry level position as a medical technologist is a bachelor's degree in medical technology or one of the life sciences. An associate degree from a college or technical institute usually qualifies you for a position as an assistant or medical laboratory technician. Some states require that medical technologists be registered or licensed.

Nuclear Medicine Technologist.title: Nuclear Medicine Technologist
Nuclear Medicine Technologist.jobTasks: Nuclear Medicine Technologist administer radiopharmaceuticals or radiation intravenously to detect or treat diseases, using radioisotope equipment, under direction of a physician. They detect and map radiopharmaceuticals in patients' bodies, using a camera to produce photographic or computer images. They calculate, measure and record radiation dosage or radiopharmaceuticals received, used and disposed, using computer and following physician's prescription.They will also perform quality control checks on laboratory equipment and cameras.
Nuclear Medicine Technologist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 62,910 and $ 88,610 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $101,850.
Nuclear Medicine Technologist.training: Training for this occupation generally requires an Associate Degree from a 2 year or community college.

Nuclear Monitoring Technician.title: Nuclear Monitoring Technician
Nuclear Monitoring Technician.jobTasks: Calculate safe radiation exposure times for personnel using plant contamination readings and prescribed safe levels of radiation. Inform supervisors when individual exposures or area radiation levels approach maximum permissible limits. Monitor personnel to determine the amounts and intensities of radiation exposure. Provide initial response to abnormal events or to alarms from radiation monitoring equipment. Collect samples of air, water, gases, or solids to determine radioactivity levels of contamination. Instruct personnel in radiation safety procedures and demonstrate use of protective clothing and equipment. Determine intensities and types of radiation in work areas, equipment, or materials, using radiation detectors or other instruments. Set up equipment that automatically detects area radiation deviations and test detection equipment to ensure its accuracy. Determine or recommend radioactive decontamination procedures, according to the size and nature of equipment and the degree of contamination. Place radioactive waste, such as sweepings and broken sample bottles, into containers for disposal.
Nuclear Monitoring Technician.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 61,780 and $ 95,000 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $106,950.
Nuclear Monitoring Technician.training: Training for this occupation generally requires a High School Degree, plus additional coursework in a vocational or technical school. In some cases, employers may require an Associate Degree.

Ophthalmic Laboratory Technician.title: Ophthalmic Laboratory Technician
Ophthalmic Laboratory Technician.jobTasks: Adjust lenses and frames to correct alignment. Mount, secure, and align finished lenses in frames or optical assemblies, using precision hand tools. Mount and secure lens blanks or optical lenses in holding tools or chucks of cutting, polishing, grinding, or coating machines. Shape lenses appropriately so that they can be inserted into frames. Assemble eyeglass frames and attach shields, nose pads, and temple pieces, using pliers, screwdrivers, and drills. Inspect lens blanks to detect flaws, verify smoothness of surface, and ensure thickness of coating on lenses. Clean finished lenses and eyeglasses, using cloths and solvents. Select lens blanks, molds, tools, and polishing or grinding wheels, according to production specifications. Examine prescriptions, work orders, or broken or used eyeglasses to determine specifications for lenses, contact lenses, or other optical elements. Set dials and start machines to polish lenses or hold lenses against rotating wheels to polish them manually.
Ophthalmic Laboratory Technician.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 25,130 and $ 38,850 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 51,830.
Ophthalmic Laboratory Technician.training: Training for this occupation generally requires a High School Degree, plus additional coursework in a vocational or technical school. In some cases, employers may require an Associate Degree.

Ophthalmic Medical Technicians.title: Ophthalmic Medical Technicians
Ophthalmic Medical Technicians.jobTasks: Take and document patients' medical histories. Conduct tonometry or tonography tests to measure intraocular pressure. Operate ophthalmic equipment, such as autorefractors, phoropters, tomographs, or retinoscopes. Take anatomical or functional ocular measurements of the eye or surrounding tissue, such as axial length measurements. Measure visual acuity, including near, distance, pinhole, or dynamic visual acuity, using appropriate tests.
Ophthalmic Medical Technicians.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 29,940 and $ 46,320 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 56,370.

Ophthalmic Medical Technologists.title: Ophthalmic Medical Technologists
Ophthalmic Medical Technologists.jobTasks: Conduct tonometry or tonography tests to measure intraocular pressure. Take and document patients' medical histories. Take anatomical or functional ocular measurements, such as axial length measurements, of the eye or surrounding tissue. Measure visual acuity, including near, distance, pinhole, or dynamic visual acuity, using appropriate tests. Administer topical ophthalmic or oral medications.
Ophthalmic Medical Technologists.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 29,940 and $ 46,320 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 56,370.

Orthodontic Assistant.title: Orthodontic Assistant
Orthodontic Assistant.jobTasks:
An Assistants' main duty is to help the orthodontic specialist in alignment of teeth by performing much of the 'hands-on' work needed to adjust braces.
In addition, they take x-rays, make impressions of teeth, take high quality photographs of patient' faces and teeth and interact with patients and their families.
There are many other duties that vary from office to office.
Orthodontic Assistant.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 30,410 and $ 45,170 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 52,000.
Orthodontic Assistant.training: Requirements: high school diploma, customer service skills, excellent eye-hand coordination, computer skills (important in many practices for inputting patient records, computer imaging, etc.). Certification available (but not required). The orthodontist may arrange for special training.

Orthodontic Laboratory Technician.title: Orthodontic Laboratory Technician
Orthodontic Laboratory Technician.jobTasks:
Typical Responsibilities: prepare orthodontic study models, make orthodontic retainers, design appliances for tooth and bone movement, coordinate office needs with outside labs.
The technician may also work with the orthodontist to develop skills for making new appliances.
Orthodontic Laboratory Technician.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 28,760 and $ 49,460 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 61,970.
Orthodontic Laboratory Technician.training: Most orthodontic laboratory technicians learn their craft on-the-job and require about two to three years of working experience to become fully skilled. Formal training programs are available in applied technical institutes and community colleges which can take up to two years to earn an associate degree. Such training must include hands-on work experience in a laboratory. Courses in art, metal work and science are helpful.

Phlebotomist.title: Phlebotomist
Phlebotomist.jobTasks:
Interview patients or blood donors to collect medical history information as it might relate to diseases and for the screening of blood to be used in blood transfusions.
They measure vital signs such as blood pressure, temperature and pulse prior to drawing blood. Apply tourniquet and draw blood samples in accord with physicians' requests.
They prepare identification labels for a patient's or donor's blood sample and perform blood analysis for classifying, typing and testing blood for abnormalities.
Perform administrative record keeping for each blood drawing. They report findings of blood abnormalities to physicians, and store blood samples for further processing and analysis.
Phlebotomist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 27,350 and $ 38,800 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 46,850.
Phlebotomist.training: Formal training which leads to a certificate are offered by vocational-technical schools, technical institutes and community colleges. Most programs last 6 months to a year and consist of courses in anatomy, physiology, hematology, medical lab techniques, clinical skills used in blood drawing, first aid and medical office administration.

Physical Therapy Assistant.title: Physical Therapy Assistant
Physical Therapy Assistant.jobTasks:
They instruct patients in a variety of manual exercise treatments with equipment such as treadmills, stationary bikes and weight lifting machines. They also conduct swimming exercises.
They administer massages, electrical stimulation, paraffin baths, ultrasound, hot/cold packs and traction. They measure and assess the patient's flexibility and range of motion.
They assist physical therapists in the fitting of orthopedic braces and prosthetic devices on patients. They instruct patients how to use these devices.
They monitor patient progress throughout the prescribed treatment plan and report significant problems, abnormalities and achievements to the physical therapist.
Physical Therapy Assistant.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 45,840 and $ 66,860 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 79,040.
Physical Therapy Assistant.training: An associate degree from an accredited physical therapist assistant program is the appropriate educational background for this occupation. Most states require assistants to be certified or licensed and have certification in CPR, first aid and clinical working experience.

Radiologic Technicians.title: Radiologic Technicians
Radiologic Technicians.jobTasks: Maintain and use equipment and supplies necessary to demonstrate portions the human body on X-ray film or fluoroscopic screen for diagnostic purposes.
Radiologic Technicians.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 46,490 and $ 70,430 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 82,590.
Radiologic Technicians.training: Training for this occupation generally requires an Associate Degree from a 2 year or community college.

Radiologic Technologist.title: Radiologic Technologist
Radiologic Technologist.jobTasks:
They apply roentgen rays (X-rays) and radioactive substances to patients for diagnostic & therapeutic purposes. Position the patient under X-ray machines and adjust equipment and plates.
They read physician's requests for body location and angles needed. Regulate length and intensity of exposure based on patient's body characteristics.
They assist the physician in exposing cancerous areas of body for specified periods of time. May also assist in therapy with radium or radioactive isotopes.
They determine if the X-rays taken provide details needed for radiologist's diagnostic readings and decide whether additional X-rays are needed for diagnosis.
Radiologic Technologist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 46,490 and $ 70,430 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 82,590.
Radiologic Technologist.training: A two-year college associate degree or a technical institute certificate in radiography, radiation therapy and sonography is the usual preparation for this field. Some employers, however, prefer candidates with a bachelor's degree. Many states require radiological technologists to be licensed.

Respiratory Care Technician.title: Respiratory Care Technician
Respiratory Care Technician.jobTasks:
They confer with physicians to determine which pulmonary tests are required for given patients. Tests include blood-oxygen levels, helium, red cell count and expired air content.
They counsel and demonstrate to patients how they are to use the equipment that measures their maximum breathing capacity and capture their expired air for analysis.
They combine tests results with those from cardio-vascular tests. They summarize test findings, interpret results and report conclusions to physicians. They explain unusual findings.
They notify reliability and accuracy of laboratory test equipment used and calibrate the measurement devices by conducting standardized procedures supplied by the manufacturers.
Respiratory Care Technician.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 37,690 and $ 73,050 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 89,450.
Respiratory Care Technician.training: Technical institutes offer respiratory care technician programs that require 12 to 15 months to complete. Community colleges offer two-year associate degree programs for respiratory therapy. Areas of study include anatomy, physiology, microbiology, chemistry, therapy procedures, equipment and clinical tests. Certification by examination is given by the National Board for Respiratory Care.

Respiratory Therapist.title: Respiratory Therapist
Respiratory Therapist.jobTasks:
They test the capacity of patient's lungs and measure the amount of oxygen, carbon dioxide and acidity of the blood flowing through the patient's lungs.
They administer medication by means of aerosol or other means to expand the capacity of a patient's lungs. They instruct the patient in therapeutic breathing exercises.
They attach breathing and respiratory aids and devices to patients. Check device reading and draw blood samples from patients to ensure proper oxygen level.
They meet with the physicians' medical team to review patient's progress and determine future respiratory treatments. They may perform chest physiotherapy to clear patient's lungs.
Respiratory Therapist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 49,340 and $ 70,650 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 81,550.
Respiratory Therapist.training: The usual educational requirement for respiratory therapists is a 2-year training program leading to an Associate Degree. There are, however, four-year college bachelor degree programs. Most states require licensing involving a state examination.

Respiratory Therapy Technicians.title: Respiratory Therapy Technicians
Respiratory Therapy Technicians.jobTasks: Provide specific, well defined respiratory care procedures under the direction of respiratory therapists and physicians.
Respiratory Therapy Technicians.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 40,040 and $ 60,730 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 72,970.
Respiratory Therapy Technicians.training: Training for this occupation generally requires an Associate Degree from a 2 year or community college.

Surgical Assistants.title: Surgical Assistants
Surgical Assistants.jobTasks: Verify the identity of patient or operative site. Monitor and maintain aseptic technique throughout procedures. Cover patients with surgical drapes to create and maintain a sterile operative field. Coordinate or participate in the positioning of patients, using body stabilizing equipment or protective padding to provide appropriate exposure for the procedure or to protect against nerve damage or circulation impairment. Maintain an unobstructed operative field, using surgical retractors, sponges, or suctioning and irrigating equipment.
Surgical Assistants.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 35,170 and $ 76,020 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $103,430.

Surgical Technician/Technologist.title: Surgical Technician/Technologist
Surgical Technician/Technologist.jobTasks:
They study the patient's surgery plan as specified by the surgeon. Set up operating rooms with surgical instruments, equipment, linens, and fluids needed during the surgery.
Prepare patients for surgery by shaving and disinfecting body areas. They confer with nurses to assure patient received pre-operative diet and care. Transport patients to operating room.
During surgery, they pass instruments and supplies to surgeons and nurses. Keep accurate accounting of all materials prior to, during and after surgery so that none were left in the patient.
They help prepare, care for and dispose of patient body specimens taken for laboratory analysis during operation. They monitor patient's removal to recovery room and presence of nurses.
Surgical Technician/Technologist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 36,980 and $ 55,030 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 64,800.
Surgical Technician/Technologist.training: Training programs offered by technical institutes require about 14 months and lead to a certificate or a diploma. Community colleges offer two-year associate degree programs. Curriculum includes anatomy, physiology, pharmacology, biology and medical technical terminology.

Ultrasound Technologist.title: Ultrasound Technologist
Ultrasound Technologist.jobTasks:
They operate ultrasound diagnostic equipment to produce 2-dimensional patterns and positive pictures of internal organs and muscles for diagnosis of diseases and malfunction.
They perform ultrasound analyses for pre-natal examination of a pregnant female's fetus and placenta. They adjust equipment according to the part of body examined.
They explain to patients the procedures used and assist patients to assume physical positions needed for the required exposure to ultrasonic waves.
They review tests results with physicians to identify and locate suspected abnormalities and ambiguities and decide whether additional tests will clarify ambiguous areas.
Ultrasound Technologist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 57,530 and $ 82,320 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 99,100.
Ultrasound Technologist.training: An associate degree or a technical institute certificate with a major in sonography is the usual educational requirement. In addition to core courses in health science, special studies are required in acoustical physics, human anatomy, physiology and cardiac anatomy.

Dental Assistant.title: Dental Assistant
Dental Assistant.jobTasks:
They give preliminary examinations of a patient's teeth just before the dentist examines the patient. This includes X-rays, gum examination and search for decay and loss of fillings.
They make wax impressions of patient's teeth for the purpose of making bridge casts and crowns. They send impressions to a dental laboratory and check quality of the laboratory's castings.
They assist the dentist during patient treatment by selection of instruments, mixing materials for fillings, removing mouth saliva, flushing, etc. They adjust patient's braces.
They record dentist's diagnosis and treatment for each patient in a filing system along with X-rays. They confer with people performing patient invoicing to assure accurate fees are charged.
Dental Assistant.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 30,410 and $ 45,170 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 52,000.
Dental Assistant.training: Technical institutes offer training programs that usually take one year to complete and lead to a certificate or diploma. Two year college associate degrees are also available. Certification can be achieved by passing an examination by the Dental Assistant National Board.

Dental Hygienist.title: Dental Hygienist
Dental Hygienist.jobTasks:
They clean patient's teeth using hand instruments to remove plaque stains. Instruments used include scaling devices, electric brushes, picks and mirrors.
They visually diagnose patient's problems for the dentist such as decays, tooth fracture, gum disease, deterioration of fillings, and crown and caps.
They report patient's teeth condition to the dentist for further examination and treatment. They maintain patient's records.
They teach the patient how to select and use mouth care products such as dental floss, cleaners and prescribed treatments.
Dental Hygienist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 60,500 and $ 86,390 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $100,170.
Dental Hygienist.training: Employment of dental hygienists is expected to be much faster than average through 2018. It is one of the fastest growing occupations due to the aging of the population, the demand for better dental care by consumers, and the tendency for people to keep their teeth longer.

Dental Laboratory Technician.title: Dental Laboratory Technician
Dental Laboratory Technician.jobTasks:
They fill prescriptions for crowns, bridges and dentures. They start with 'impressions' (molds) of the patient's mouth or teeth and specifications submitted by the dentist.
They create a model of the patient's mouth by pouring plaster into the impression and use the model to duplicate the bite and movement of the patient's jaws.
The model is used by the technician to build and shape a wax tooth, or teeth using small hand instruments such as spatulas and wax carvers.
Using the wax model, they pour and cast a metal framework for the prosthetic device and then apply layers of porcelain to arrive at the exact shape and color specified by the dentist.
Dental Laboratory Technician.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 28,760 and $ 49,460 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 61,970.
Dental Laboratory Technician.training: Most dental laboratory technicians learn their craft on-the-job and require about three years of working experience to become fully skilled. Formal training programs are available in applied technical institutes and community colleges which can take up to two years to earn an associate degree. Such training must include hands-on work experience in a dental laboratory. Courses in art, metal work and science are helpful.

Dentist (DDS).title: Dentist (DDS)
Dentist (DDS).jobTasks:
They diagnose patient's problems with teeth and gums for purposes of prevention and correction of diseases, decay, malformations and injuries.
They use his/her fine hand-eye coordination skills to drill and grind teeth using hand-held instruments, drills and other equipment.
They make wax impressions for bridges, crowns and caps. Match shades of white of patient's teeth with those available bridges. Fit final products by fine grinding of teeth and the appliance.
The interpret patient X-rays to diagnose tooth and gum condition and problems. Refer patients for further care to specialists such as oral surgeons and orthodontists.
Dentist (DDS).earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $106,180 and $221,200 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $320,000.
Dentist (DDS).training: All states require dentists to be licensed. Licensing requires graduation from an accredited dental school and passing written and practical exams. In addition to completing four years of dental school, most dentists have a bachelor's degree from a 4-year college. Dental schools require a minimum of two years of pre-dental college training.

Orthodontist (MD).title: Orthodontist (MD)
Orthodontist (MD).jobTasks:
They diagnose the causes of a patient's mouth and dental abnormalities in the jaw, mouth and teeth. Determine whether the abnormalities can be corrected with braces and devices.
May prescribe the removal of teeth or surgery as a preliminary step to the design of braces and devices to realign the patient's teeth or jaw.
They determine for each patient whether orthodontic corrective methods are needed for reasons of the health of teeth, mouth and jaws or for improving appearance.
Design actual braces, wires and other devices needed for each patient. Make adjustments on the devices as patient improves. Design devices patients can insert & remove for long term usage.
Orthodontist (MD).earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $150,060 and $300,120 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $380,000.
Orthodontist (MD).training: All states require orthodontists to be licensed. Licensing requires graduation from an accredited dental school and passing written and practical exams. In addition to completing four years of dental school, most orthodontists have a bachelor's degree from a 4-year college including specialized training. Dental schools require a minimum of two years of pre-dental college training.

Periodontist.title: Periodontist
Periodontist.jobTasks:
Surgical techniques include the removal of infected gingival tissues, treatment of root surfaces via open flap procedures, new regenerative procedures, placement of synthetic bone substitutes in periodontal defects, and the recontouring of healthy tissues prior to prosthetic construction and restorative procedures.
Non-surgical procedures include local debridement through scaling and root planing, antibiotic therapy when indicated, and patient instruction in appropriate plaque removal techniques at home.
The successful practice of periodontics relies heavily on the dental hygienist as an integral member of the health care team. Periodontists routinely employ one or more hygienists to perform non-surgical procedures such as scaling, oral prophylaxis and patient home care instruction.
Periodontist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $106,180 and $221,200 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $320,000.
Periodontist.training: All training programs require successful completion of the Dental Admission Test. All states require dentists to be licensed. Licensing requires graduation from an accredited dental school and passing written and practical exams.
