They meet with product development managers during the early stages of development of new products to identify product features that should be stressed in advertising campaigns. They decide what kind of market research studies to conduct to measure how well products and services meet customer needs. They plan test marketing experiments with targeted customer groups.Design sales orientation programs and materials to train their company's salespersons how to sell new products and services. Decide on sales promotion incentives to attract new customers.
Advertising Sales Agent.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 34,380 and $ 76,050 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $115,430.
Advertising Sales Agent.training: A bachelor's degree in business administration with a concentration on advertising and communications is the ideal preparation for this field. Courses in advertising, marketing, statistics, consumer behavior, communications and visual arts are essential. Most employers prefer to hire new graduates in assistant positions in market planning in preparation for sales promotion administration jobs. College graduates with creativity, experience and excellent communication skills will have the best opportunities.

Market Research Analyst.title: Market Research Analyst
Market Research Analyst.jobTasks: Design survey questionnaires and interviews to collect data from potential cutomers about their receptivity and needs for new products and services. Statistically analyze survey data to see how customers in different industries, locations, and size differ in their needs and how much they are willing to spend for new products. Make decisions about design specifications for new products, their prices, and the marketing strategy to sell the products or services. They also estimate sales volume and revenue forecasts. Make oral presentations to executives to recommend the types of product lines and services to consider for the future based on the results of their surveys. Prepare written summary reports.
Market Research Analyst.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 53,200 and $ 88,690 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $100,800.
Market Research Analyst.training: A Bachelor's degree with a major in marketing, business administration or economics is appropriate for most entry level positions. Because of the importance of quantitative skills in market research, courses in mathematics, statistics, econometrics, survey design and computer science are recommended. Graduate training and an MBA are important for advancement.

Marketing Managers.title: Marketing Managers
Marketing Managers.jobTasks: Formulate, direct and coordinate marketing activities and policies to promote products and services, working with advertising and promotion managers. Identify, develop, or evaluate marketing strategy, based on knowledge of establishment objectives, market characteristics, and cost and markup factors. Direct the hiring, training, or performance evaluations of marketing or sales staff and oversee their daily activities. Evaluate the financial aspects of product development, such as budgets, expenditures, research and development appropriations, or return-on-investment and profit-loss projections. Develop pricing strategies, balancing firm objectives and customer satisfaction. Compile lists describing product or service offerings. Initiate market research studies or analyze their findings. Use sales forecasting or strategic planning to ensure the sale and profitability of products, lines, or services, analyzing business developments and monitoring market trends. Coordinate or participate in promotional activities or trade shows, working with developers, advertisers, or production managers, to market products or services. Consult with buying personnel to gain advice regarding the types of products or services expected to be in demand.
Marketing Managers.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 53,200 and $ 88,690 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $100,800.
Marketing Managers.training: Typically, a Bachelorâ€™s Degree from a 4-year college (some are 5 years) is required to be considered for this occupation.

Search Marketing Strategists.title: Search Marketing Strategists
Search Marketing Strategists.jobTasks: Collect and analyze Web metrics, such as visits, time on site, page views per visit, transaction volume and revenue, traffic mix, click-through rates, conversion rates, cost per acquisition, or cost per click. Identify appropriate Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) and report key metrics from digital campaigns. Assist in setting up or optimizing analytics tools for tracking visitors' behaviors. Coordinate with developers to optimize Web site architecture, server configuration, or page construction for search engine consumption and optimal visibility. Conduct online marketing initiatives, such as paid ad placement, affiliate programs, sponsorship programs, email promotions, or viral marketing campaigns on social media Web sites. Participate in the development or implementation of online marketing strategy.
Search Marketing Strategists.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 46,800 and $ 89,580 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $122,630.
Search Marketing Strategists.training: Typically, a Bachelorâ€™s Degree from a 4-year college (some are 5 years) is required to be considered for this occupation.

Sales Engineers.title: Sales Engineers
Sales Engineers.jobTasks: Sell business goods or services, the selling of which requires a technical background equivalent to a baccalaureate degree in engineering.
Sales Engineers.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 74,400 and $132,080 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $166,500.
Sales Engineers.training: Training for this occupation generally requires an Associate Degree from a 2 year or community college.

Sales Managers.title: Sales Managers
Sales Managers.jobTasks: Direct the actual distribution or movement of a product or service to the customer. Coordinate sales distribution by establishing sales territories, quotas, and goals and establish training programs for sales representatives. Analyze sales statistics gathered by staff to determine sales potential and inventory requirements and monitor the preferences of customers.
Sales Managers.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 79,420 and $168,300 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $208,000.
Sales Managers.training: Typically, a Bachelorâ€™s Degree from a 4-year college (some are 5 years) is required to be considered for this occupation.

Retail Sales Department Supervisor.title: Retail Sales Department Supervisor
Retail Sales Department Supervisor.jobTasks: Retail sales department supervisors oversee the work of salespeople within a specialized department of a store. They direct and supervise employees engaged in sales, inventory, customer assistance and reconcile cash receipts. Supervisors hire, train and evaluate salespeople. During training, they teach and assist salespeople with difficult sales procedures, such as returns and exchanges. Once salespeople have experience, supervisors evaluate their work and suggest ways salespeople can improve their sales skills. The administrative duties of a retail sales department supervisor include developing work schedules, assigning workers to different duties and keeping records of employees hours. In addition, supervisors take inventory of the merchandise and reorder items that are out of stock. They examine merchandise to ensure it is correctly priced and properly displayed. They also keep track of which items sell quickly. Supervisors occasionally write reports about their departments' sales and purchases. They attend meetings and suggest ways for store officials to increase sales. Retail sales department supervisors talk to customers about products, services, and personnel. They listen to and resolve conflicts between customer complaints regarding service, personnel, and products. Most retail sales department supervisors have offices within the stores, usually close to the area they oversee. Although, some time is spent in the office completing merchandise orders or arranging work schedules, a large portion of their workday is spent on the sales floor, supervising employees or selling.
Retail Sales Department Supervisor.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 30,370 and $ 51,250 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 66,480.
Retail Sales Department Supervisor.training: Some employers require applicants to have a bachelor's degree. Recommended areas of study are business, accounting, marketing or administration. Most employers prefer applicants who have experience in retail sales. Employers look for applicants who have team building and strong leadership skills. Supervisors learn their skills through work experience in retail sales. Many companies provide in-house training programs that last from one to three years.

Customer Service Representative.title: Customer Service Representative
Customer Service Representative.jobTasks: Confer with customers by telephone or in person to provide information about products or services, take or enter orders, cancel accounts, or obtain details of complaints. Keep records of customer interactions or transactions, recording details of inquiries, complaints, or comments, as well as actions taken. Check to ensure that appropriate changes were made to resolve customers' problems. Determine charges for services requested, collect deposits or payments, or arrange for billing. Refer unresolved customer grievances to designated departments for further investigation. Review insurance policy terms to determine whether a particular loss is covered by insurance. Contact customers to respond to inquiries or to notify them of claim investigation results or any planned adjustments. Resolve customers' service or billing complaints by performing activities such as exchanging merchandise, refunding money, or adjusting bills. Compare disputed merchandise with original requisitions and information from invoices and prepare invoices for returned goods. Obtain and examine all relevant information to assess validity of complaints and to determine possible causes, such as extreme weather conditions that could increase utility bills.
Customer Service Representative.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 25,520 and $ 41,430 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 53,730.
Customer Service Representative.training: To work as a Customer Service Rep., you should have at least a high school education. You should possess basic skills in English, Math, Computers, and have good Communication and Interpersonal skills. High schools, adult education, and community colleges offer courses in word processing and computers that are helpful in getting a job. Many companies provide on-the-job training.

Customer Service Supervisor.title: Customer Service Supervisor
Customer Service Supervisor.jobTasks: Resolve customer complaints or answer customers' questions regarding policies and procedures. Supervise the work of office, administrative, or customer service employees to ensure adherence to quality standards, deadlines, and proper procedures, correcting errors or problems. Provide employees with guidance in handling difficult or complex problems or in resolving escalated complaints or disputes. Implement corporate or departmental policies, procedures, and service standards in conjunction with management. Discuss job performance problems with employees to identify causes and issues and to work on resolving problems. Train or instruct employees in job duties or company policies or arrange for training to be provided. Evaluate employees' job performance and conformance to regulations and recommend appropriate personnel action. Review records or reports pertaining to activities such as production, payroll, or shipping to verify details, monitor work activities, or evaluate performance. Recruit, interview, and select employees. Interpret and communicate work procedures and company policies to staff.
Customer Service Supervisor.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 41,910 and $ 69,260 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 87,690.
Customer Service Supervisor.training: Training for this occupation generally requires an Associate Degree from a 2 year or community college.

Fund Raiser.title: Fund Raiser
Fund Raiser.jobTasks: They plan and design methods for raising voluntary contributions to funds such as radio and TV advertising, mailing appeals, charity balls, raffles and door to door canvassing. They work with clients, such as universities, charities and political parties to identify the amounts of funds needed and the organizations and persons most likely to contribute. They conduct studies to determine willingness of contributors to donate monies to the funds and factors that motivate them to contribute. They contract for services needed to implement fund raising activities such as advertising, printed materials and temporary workforce needed to contact potential donators.
Fund Raiser.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 41,190 and $ 71,660 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 91,530.
Fund Raiser.training: A bachelor's degree in communications is the appropriate educational background to prepare for this occupation. However, other liberal arts studies in sociology, business administration, psychology, etc. can also qualify you for this occupation. Courses in journalism, communications media, advertising, accounting, statistics and economics will strengthen your qualifications.

Fundraising Manager.title: Fundraising Manager
Fundraising Manager.jobTasks: They plan and conduct surveys to determine types of persons and organizations likely to contribute money to a project such as restoration of buildings, new buildings, political events, etc. They make estimates of the amount of time and resources needed to raise a given amount of money. They report findings to the executive of the fund raising project. They design and implement fund raising plans by contracting for services such as advertising, printed materials and temporary workforce needed to contact potential donators. They confer with executives during project planning phases to identify project characteristics and project ammouncement strategy that would motivate contributions.
Fundraising Manager.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 78,710 and $151,970 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $205,110.
Fundraising Manager.training: A bachelor's degree in communications is the appropriate educational background to prepare for this occupation. However, other liberal arts majors in sociology, business administration, psychology, etc. can also qualify you for this occupation. Courses in journalism, communications media, advertising, accounting, statistics and economics will strengthen your qualifications.

Public Relations Manager.title: Public Relations Manager
Public Relations Manager.jobTasks: Plan and direct public relations programs designed to create and maintain a favorable public image for employer or client; or if engaged in fundraising, plan and direct activities to solicit and maintain funds for special projects and nonprofit organizations.
Public Relations Manager.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 78,710 and $151,970 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $205,110.
Public Relations Manager.training: Typically, a Bachelorâ€™s Degree from a 4-year college (some are 5 years) is required to be considered for this occupation.

Public Relations Specialist.title: Public Relations Specialist
Public Relations Specialist.jobTasks: They determine what the goals, management philosophy, products, services and role of an organization are. Determine what kind of an image should be portrayed based on their characteristics. They propose advertising and communication themes to reflect the image desired by the organization. Confer with executives to get their concurrence. Manage writers and artists who create the advertising materials and exhibits used to communicate the organization's themes. Advise the organization's architects about the image desired. They design and conduct surveys of the organization's customers, clients and the general public to measure the extent their opinions are in agreement with the desired image.
Public Relations Specialist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 42,450 and $ 79,650 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $110,560.
Public Relations Specialist.training: For public relations positions, many employers prefer a bachelor's or master's degree in public relations or journalism. The study program should include courses in advertising, business administration, public affairs, political science, and creative and technical writing.

Barber.title: Barber
Barber.jobTasks: Clean and sterilize scissors, combs, clippers, and other instruments. Cut and trim hair according to clients' instructions and/or current hairstyles, using clippers, combs, hand-held blow driers, and scissors. Drape and pin protective cloths around customers' shoulders. Question patrons regarding desired services and haircut styles. Clean work stations and sweep floors. Record services provided on cashiers' tickets or receive payment from customers. Order supplies. Shape and trim beards and moustaches, using scissors. Stay informed of the latest styles and hair care techniques. Suggest treatments to alleviate hair problems.
Barber.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 20,350 and $ 37,020 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 47,400.
Barber.training: Prospective workers can be trained as a barber or hairstylist in a vocational school or a barber college. A full-time course usually takes from six to twelve months to complete. All states require barbers and hairstylists to be licensed. The qualifications necessary to get a license vary from state to state, but generally individuals must be at least sixteen years old, in good health, and a graduate of an approved barber school. In most cases candidates need to take a test to get an apprentice license after graduating from barber school. Then they must serve one or two years as an apprentice. To qualify for a barber's license, individuals must take several tests, including a written section and a practical demonstration of skills. To do some procedures, such as giving a permanent wave, candidates will also need a cosmetology license.

Cosmetologist (Hair Stylist).title: Cosmetologist (Hair Stylist)
Cosmetologist (Hair Stylist).jobTasks: They advise customers how their hair should be treated, trimmed, colored or curled based on their facial features, age and hair characteristics. They suggest to customers the home care needed for mis-managed hair such as shampooing, conditioning, brushing and combing. They give facials, nail treatment and scalp treatments. They study new hair fashion styles and attend training workshops to learn new techniques. They select and purchase new equipment, hair tools and hair care products for resale to customers. They make recommendations to customers about which brands of hair care products to use based on the customer's hair condition, color and hair style preferences.
Cosmetologist (Hair Stylist).earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 19,550 and $ 34,170 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 49,050.
Cosmetologist (Hair Stylist).training: All states require cosmetologists to be licensed. This is accomplished by graduating from a state licensed technical institute or cosmetology school and passing a physical exam, written exam and a practical exam. Most training programs require twelve to fourteen months to complete.

Manicurists and Pedicurists.title: Manicurists and Pedicurists
Manicurists and Pedicurists.jobTasks: Clean and sanitize tools and work environment. Schedule client appointments and accept payments. Remove previously applied nail polish, using liquid remover and swabs. Clean customers' nails in soapy water, using swabs, files, and orange sticks. Shape and smooth ends of nails, using scissors, files, or emery boards. Apply undercoat and clear or colored polish onto nails with brush. Advise clients on nail care and use of products and colors. Assess the condition of clients' hands, remove dead skin from the hands and massage them. Soften nail cuticles with water and oil, push back cuticles, using cuticle knife, and trim cuticles, using scissors or nippers. Brush powder and solvent onto nails and paper forms to maintain nail appearance and to extend nails, then remove forms and shape and smooth nail edges using rotary abrasive wheel.
Manicurists and Pedicurists.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 19,910 and $ 26,440 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 33,590.
Manicurists and Pedicurists.training: The typical training required for this career is generally a High School Degree or GED Certificate.

Personal Service Supervisor.title: Personal Service Supervisor
Personal Service Supervisor.jobTasks: Supervise and coordinate activities of personal service workers, such as supervisors of flight attendants, hairdressers, or caddies.
Personal Service Supervisor.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 28,280 and $ 48,160 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 61,850.
Personal Service Supervisor.training: Training for this occupation generally requires an Associate Degree from a 2 year or community college.

Skin Care Specialist.title: Skin Care Specialist
Skin Care Specialist.jobTasks: Provide skin care treatments to face and body to enhance an individual's appearance.
Skin Care Specialist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 21,960 and $ 42,810 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 59,780.
Skin Care Specialist.training: The typical training required for this career is generally a High School Degree or GED Certificate.

Administrative Law Judge.title: Administrative Law Judge
Administrative Law Judge.jobTasks: Prepare written opinions and decisions. Monitor and direct the activities of trials and hearings to ensure that they are conducted fairly and that courts administer justice while safeguarding the legal rights of all involved parties. Determine existence and amount of liability according to current laws, administrative and judicial precedents, and available evidence. Research and analyze laws, regulations, policies, and precedent decisions to prepare for hearings and to determine conclusions. Conduct hearings to review and decide claims regarding issues such as social program eligibility, environmental protection, and enforcement of health and safety regulations. Review and evaluate data on documents, such as claim applications, birth or death certificates, and physician or employer records. Recommend the acceptance or rejection of claims or compromise settlements according to laws, regulations, policies, and precedent decisions. Rule on exceptions, motions, and admissibility of evidence. Confer with individuals or organizations involved in cases to obtain relevant information. Issue subpoenas and administer oaths in preparation for formal hearings.
Administrative Law Judge.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 62,950 and $122,700 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $162,400.
Administrative Law Judge.training: A bachelorâ€™s degree and work experience usually constitute the minimum requirements. Federal administrative law judges must be lawyers and pass a competitive examination administered by the U.S. Office of Personnel Management. Some state administrative law judges and other hearing officials are not required to be lawyers. Federal administrative law judges must be lawyers and pass a competitive examination administered by the U.S. Office of Personnel Management. Some state administrative law judges and other hearing officials are not required to be lawyers.

Admiralty Lawyer.title: Admiralty Lawyer
Admiralty Lawyer.jobTasks: They manage lawsuit actions by determining the law applicable set by the constitution, statutes and regulations as related to maritime accidents, registrations, commerce and pollutions by oilspills. They research the appropriate law in a law library, interviews witnesses, and studies evidence to determine legal strategy in a lawsuit. They estimate the size of claims based on past cases. They advise clients on their legal rights, whether to prosecute and possible defenses. They study international laws of the sea to identify the basis for legal claims. They negotiate settlements for their clients in order to avoid excessive time, costs and legal risks. They arrange for marine insurance to protect ship owner assets.
Admiralty Lawyer.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 77,580 and $176,580 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $250,000.
Admiralty Lawyer.training: To practice law in the courts of any state, a person must be licensed or admitted to its Bar by passing an examination. To qualify for the exam, you must complete at least four years of college and graduate from an approved law school.

Appeals Examiner.title: Appeals Examiner
Appeals Examiner.jobTasks:
Appeals referees arrange for and conduct legal hearings to investigate facts in cases where persons or organizations have made financial claims for insurance, welfare or tax benefits. They make decisions about whether the benefits claimed should be paid based on the arguments presented by the person making the claim and the party resisting the payment of the claim.
They advise persons or parties involved in the case about future state & federal guidelines they must follow. They follow up on the outcome of the decision to assure instructions were followed.
They write up decisions about each case for future reference and review by the interested persons. They research each new case by studying the decisions and results of prior cases.
Appeals Examiner.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 40,090 and $ 72,090 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 97,440.
Appeals Examiner.training: To qualify for a position as an appeals referee in any state, you generally must be licensed or admitted to the State's Bar by passing an examination. To qualify for the exam you must complete a four-year college program and graduate from an approved law school.

Arbitrator.title: Arbitrator
Arbitrator.jobTasks:
They analyze the causes of disputes between the management of an organization and the leaders of a union. Evaluate the logic and validity of their arguments and the positions they have taken.
They study the specific terms and conditions of the existing contract that both parties had agreed upon earlier and identify and clarify ambiguities in the contract or arguments presented.
They make decisions that will settle the dispute as fairly as possible and are compatible with the existing contract. They attempt to minimize the financial losses for both parties.
They author documents to formally describe the cases and how they were settled. Perform research on past cases to determine if the decisions made successfully ended the disputes.
Arbitrator.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 42,480 and $ 88,510 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $123,930.
Arbitrator.training: A bachelor's degree or a master's degree in industrial or labor relations with special training in dispute resolution is needed in this occupation. A background in labor law, human resource management, industrial psychology, statistics and labor economics is also essential.

Attorney.title: Attorney
Attorney.jobTasks:
They interpret the law and apply it to their client's specific situations in order to give protection to their client or to make legal demands of their clients' opponents.
They counsel clients as to their legal rights and obligations and suggest particular courses of action in business and personnel matters. If necessary they represent their clients in court.
Conduct in-depth research of past legal decisions, of laws and circumstances which are similar to the ones of their clients. They use research results to justify their clients' arguments.
Prepare legal documents for clients such as contracts, wills, estate plans and copyrights. They create business arrrangements such as corporations and partnerships.
Attorney.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 77,580 and $176,580 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $250,000.
Attorney.training: To practice law in the courts of any state, a person must be licensed or admitted to its Bar by passing an examination. To qualify for the exam, you must complete at least four years of college and graduate from an approved law school.

Bailiff.title: Bailiff
Bailiff.jobTasks: Bailiffs enforce courtroom rules of behavior by preventing spectators or intruders from creating disturbances, distractions or physically interfering with procedures. They collect and retain from all persons in the courtroom all unauthorized weapons or potential weapons. They prevent the jury from making contact with the public. Bailiffs advise witnesses and lawyers of appropriate behavior and dress code, swears in witnesses and announces entrance of the judge. They assure that only authorized persons contact the accused. They may use physical force to stop attacks on any member of the courtroom. Bailiffs may use weapons in cases of danger. They visually scan the courtroom to detect potential disturbances.
Bailiff.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 31,700 and $ 60,930 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 74,300.
Bailiff.training: To qualify for the position of bailiff or courtroom officer at the state or local level of the court system, you are generally required to have at least an associate degree. Courses should concentrate on judicial studies, public administration, case law and business administration. Applicants are often required to pass a written and oral examination.

Corporation Lawyer.title: Corporation Lawyer
Corporation Lawyer.jobTasks: Advise corporation executives what kinds of business practices are legal or illegal in their industry. Such practices include pricing, sales methods and human resource management actions. They conduct workshops to train a corporation's managers how to comply with federal laws regarding discrimination against employees, labor relations and collective bargaining. They study legal complaints brought against a corporation in order to prepare a defense. They interview the executives, managers and employees who may have been involved. They negotiate major business transactions involving mergers between corporations or the spin-off of the corporation's operating units into separate smaller businesses.
Corporation Lawyer.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 77,580 and $176,580 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $250,000.
Corporation Lawyer.training: To practice law in the courts of any state, a person must be licensed or admitted to its Bar by passing an examination. To qualify for the exam, you must complete at least four years of college and graduate from an approved law school.

Correction Officer.title: Correction Officer
Correction Officer.jobTasks: They observe behaviors and attitudes of prisoners to anticapate if any types of inappropriate or illegal actions might occur. They search prisoners or their cells if there are concerns. Evaluate prisoners who can be paroled by making judgments about their social behaviors. They decide whether the prisoners show signs of being able to function as a free person. They advise prison administrators, physicians and psychiatrists about unusual behavior that could suggest prisoner riots, escape attempts or violence. Advise prisoners about prison living procedures, monitor their performance in training programs and prison jobs to which they are assigned. They help to avoid conflicts between prisoners.
Correction Officer.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 34,150 and $ 56,770 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 74,630.
Correction Officer.training: Correctional institutions, such as prisons, prison camps and reformatories, prefer to hire persons with an associate degree or higher. A course background in criminology, psychology, human services and law enforcement is helpful. Federal, state and local departments of correction all provide training for correction officer trainees.

Court Reporter.title: Court Reporter
Court Reporter.jobTasks: They attend court trials, hearings and depositions to objectively record all verbal statements made by persons participating in the proceedings such as lawyers, witnesses, the accused and judges. They use stenotype machines to key in short-hand symbols in order to record the statements made during the hearing. Computers are used to roughly translate the shorthand symbols into English. They edit the rough computer translation of the proceedings in order to produce a finished accurate report which can be read and understood by persons interested in the case.At legal depositions done outside a courtroom, they swear in witnesses. They are responsible for exhibits presented during the proceeding and must mark and catalog them for future reference.
Court Reporter.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 36,870 and $ 72,400 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 95,990.
Court Reporter.training: Court reporting training programs are offered by technical institutes, colleges and universities leading to certification and either an associate or a bachelor's degree. Most employers require stenotyping skills and many states require court reporters to be Notary Publics and be certified by examinations administered by the National Court Reporters Association.

Criminal Lawyer.title: Criminal Lawyer
Criminal Lawyer.jobTasks: They prepare a legal defense for clients who have been accused of a serious crime. Their defense requires an investigation of the specific case including interviews with witnesses. If the client admits to the crime, the criminal lawyer may plea bargain with the state prosecutors. This means telling all facts and hopefully receiving a lesser sentence in return. They build legal arguments to try to discredit or undermine the case being built by the prosecutors. This requires making hypotheses about how the prosecution will present their case. They interview persons being considered for placement on the jury for a case. They request the judge to eliminate jurors who seem to be against his/her client.
Criminal Lawyer.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 77,580 and $176,580 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $250,000.
Criminal Lawyer.training: To practice law in the courts of any state, a person must be licensed or admitted to its Bar by passing an examination. To qualify for the exam, you must complete at least four years of college and graduate from an approved law school.

Judge.title: Judge
Judge.jobTasks: Read documents on pleadings and motions to ascertain facts and issues. Rule on admissibility of evidence and methods of conducting testimony. Instruct juries on applicable laws, direct juries to deduce the facts from the evidence presented, and hear their verdicts. Award compensation for damages to litigants in civil cases in relation to findings by juries or by the court. Monitor proceedings to ensure that all applicable rules and procedures are followed. Preside over hearings and listen to allegations made by plaintiffs to determine whether the evidence supports the charges. Research legal issues and write opinions on the issues. Write decisions on cases. Advise attorneys, juries, litigants, and court personnel regarding conduct, issues, and proceedings. Interpret and enforce rules of procedure or establish new rules in situations where there are no procedures already established by law.
Judge.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 64,070 and $157,270 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $183,570.
Judge.training: This occupation generally requires an advanced degree (e.g. Ph.D.). The typical commitment is a minimum of 3 years of study beyond a Bachelorâ€™s or Masterâ€™s Degree.

Law Clerks.title: Law Clerks
Law Clerks.jobTasks: Attend court sessions to hear oral arguments or record necessary case information. Communicate with counsel regarding case management or procedural requirements. Confer with judges concerning legal questions, construction of documents, or granting of orders. Draft or proofread judicial opinions, decisions, or citations. Keep abreast of changes in the law and inform judges when cases are affected by such changes. Participate in conferences or discussions between trial attorneys and judges. Prepare briefs, legal memoranda, or statements of issues involved in cases, including appropriate suggestions or recommendations. Research laws, court decisions, documents, opinions, briefs, or other information related to cases before the court. Review complaints, petitions, motions, or pleadings that have been filed to determine issues involved or basis for relief. Review dockets of pending litigation to ensure adequate progress.
Law Clerks.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 41,650 and $ 69,660 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $106,640.
Law Clerks.training: Candidates for this occupation generally have completed their Bachelorâ€™s Degree and have continued their education either 1 or 2 years longer.

Legal Assistant.title: Legal Assistant
Legal Assistant.jobTasks: Prepare affidavits or other documents, such as legal correspondence, and organize and maintain documents in paper or electronic filing system. Prepare for trial by performing tasks such as organizing exhibits. Prepare legal documents, including briefs, pleadings, appeals, wills, contracts, and real estate closing statements. Meet with clients and other professionals to discuss details of case. File pleadings with court clerk. Gather and analyze research data, such as statutes, decisions, and legal articles, codes, and documents. Call upon witnesses to testify at hearing. Investigate facts and law of cases and search pertinent sources, such as public records, to determine causes of action and to prepare cases. Direct and coordinate law office activity, including delivery of subpoenas. Keep and monitor legal volumes to ensure that law library is up-to-date.
Legal Assistant.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 38,230 and $ 63,650 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 80,260.
Legal Assistant.training: Training for this occupation generally requires an Associate Degree from a 2 year or community college.

Legal Secretary.title: Legal Secretary
Legal Secretary.jobTasks: They use computer word-processing systems to type and prepare legal documents for a lawyer, judge or law firm. Documents include contracts wills, complaints and motions. They perform searches through legal journals to locate past cases and court decisions that are relevant to present cases being handled by lawyers. They confer with clients to collect records requested by lawyers as background information for a case or a legal document. They prepare drafts of such background information. They schedule client appointments for lawyers. Organize legal records, and classify them in preparation for filing or entry into a computer based information retrieval system.
Legal Secretary.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 33,510 and $ 59,410 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 75,530.
Legal Secretary.training: Law firms and government agencies dealing with legal matters and contracts prefer to hire applicants who have completed a one year technical institute training program or have a two-year associate degree or equivalent from a college or business school. The study program must prepare them for the legal field and a knowledge of computer applications. Professional certification can be achieved by a written examination after two to three years of work experience.

Legislative Assistant.title: Legislative Assistant
Legislative Assistant.jobTasks: They conduct library research for potential new laws proposed by a congress member and estimate how the new laws would impact existing laws. They write drafts of proposed laws. Attend congressional committee meetings to assess the potential of acceptance and passage of new laws by congress members. They interview lobbyists, voters & reporters for support of new laws. They analyze voting records of other congress members to forecast passage of proposed laws. They design and conduct surveys of voters to determine how to modify these laws for voter acceptance. They arrange meetings with executives from government agencies, business organizations and institutions to discuss the new laws. They write drafts of speeches for these meetings.
Legislative Assistant.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 40,410 and $ 84,030 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $127,650.
Legislative Assistant.training: A legislative assistant position is viewed as an entry position in the field of politics. A bachelor's degree in political science, complemented with a supervised internship working as an aide to an elected legislator, is the ideal preparation. In addition to political science courses, your study program should include public speaking, writing, survey design, mass communication, law, statistics and computer applications.

Legislator.title: Legislator
Legislator.jobTasks: Analyze and understand the local and national implications of proposed legislation. Appoint nominees to leadership posts, or approve such appointments. Confer with colleagues to formulate positions and strategies pertaining to pending issues. Debate the merits of proposals and bill amendments during floor sessions, following the appropriate rules of procedure. Develop expertise in subject matters related to committee assignments. Hear testimony from constituents, representatives of interest groups, board and commission members, and others with an interest in bills or issues under consideration. Keep abreast of the issues affecting constituents by making personal visits and phone calls, reading local newspapers, and viewing or listening to local broadcasts. Maintain knowledge of relevant national and international current events. Make decisions that balance the perspectives of private citizens, public officials, and party leaders. Negotiate with colleagues or members of other political parties in order to reconcile differing interests, and to create policies and agreements.
Legislator.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 18,560 and $ 67,670 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 96,500.
Legislator.training: This occupation generally requires an advanced degree (e.g. Ph.D.). The typical commitment is a minimum of 3 years of study beyond a Bachelorâ€™s or Masterâ€™s Degree.

Magistrate.title: Magistrate
Magistrate.jobTasks: Read documents on pleadings and motions to ascertain facts and issues. Rule on admissibility of evidence and methods of conducting testimony. Instruct juries on applicable laws, direct juries to deduce the facts from the evidence presented, and hear their verdicts. Award compensation for damages to litigants in civil cases in relation to findings by juries or by the court. Monitor proceedings to ensure that all applicable rules and procedures are followed. Preside over hearings and listen to allegations made by plaintiffs to determine whether the evidence supports the charges. Research legal issues and write opinions on the issues. Write decisions on cases. Advise attorneys, juries, litigants, and court personnel regarding conduct, issues, and proceedings. Interpret and enforce rules of procedure or establish new rules in situations where there are no procedures already established by law.
Magistrate.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 64,070 and $157,270 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $183,570.
Magistrate.training: This occupation generally requires an advanced degree (e.g. Ph.D.). The typical commitment is a minimum of 3 years of study beyond a Bachelorâ€™s or Masterâ€™s Degree.

Paralegal.title: Paralegal
Paralegal.jobTasks: They perform library and archive research needed to discover past legal decisions, look up legal codes, treaties and institutions to prepare a legal argument or defense. They prepare drafts of legal documents such as wills, contracts, deeds, and trusts in accordance with the state laws that regulate such contracts. They interview clients involved in a legal case to collect and organize the data and information for ease of interpretation by attorneys. They verify the accuracy of all data and information collected in support of a case or legal instrument. They advise responsible attorneys of gaps or inaccuracies.
Paralegal.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 38,230 and $ 63,650 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 80,260.
Paralegal.training: Paralegal training programs, approved by the American Bar Association, are offered in 2-year colleges and 4-year colleges, universities and law schools. Most paralegal training programs are completed in 2 years. Voluntary certification, offered by the National Association of Legal Assistants is helpful for advancement. Certification requires passing a 2-day written examination.

Patent Agent.title: Patent Agent
Patent Agent.jobTasks: They interview persons who wish to protect their ideas, innovations and inventions by means of a legal patent. They advise these clients about the probable protection offered by a patent. They help prepare the technical descriptions, samples and documentation needed to apply for a patent. They determine what types of graphics or art work is needed. They submit the patent applications in behalf of their clients to the U.S. Patent Office. They may suggest the need to file an application for trademark names and symbols. They research the patent files and legal decisions reached by courts regarding the patents for certain types of inventions and innovations. They determine how to protect the client's patents.
Patent Agent.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 38,230 and $ 63,650 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 80,260.
Patent Agent.training: A bachelor's degree from a 4-year college or university is the typical educational qualification for positions as a patent agent. The program of study should be related to the field the patent agent chooses for specialization; for example, computer software, chemical products, electronic products, etc. Business administration courses are also essential.

Patent Lawyer.title: Patent Lawyer
Patent Lawyer.jobTasks: Interview inventors and management in organizations who wish to apply for a patent to protect their inventions, innovations, computer software. They advise regarding patent requirements. They research the patent request to determine the likelihood of solid, legal protection based on past court decisions regarding the innovation in question. They assist their clients in the preparation of documentation and artwork needed to support their patent. They submit the patent application to a patent office. Prepare legal suits against those who violate their client's patents. They calculate the value of damage done by the violators and sues for compensation and discontinuation of the violation.
Patent Lawyer.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 77,580 and $176,580 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $250,000.
Patent Lawyer.training: To practice law in the courts of any state, a person must be licensed or admitted to its Bar by passing an examination. To qualify for the exam, you must complete at least four years of college and graduate from an approved law school.

Probate Lawyer.title: Probate Lawyer
Probate Lawyer.jobTasks: They analyze their client's assets and liabilities to determine how to best avoid inheritance tax and retain properties for family members and other heirs upon the death of their clients. They interview clients to determine their preferences and priorities regarding the heirs identified. With the client, they decide upon a plan and the methods for distributing properties. They draft wills, deeds and trusts for their clients to achieve the desired objectives. Advise the clients about limitations. They modify these instruments at the client's request. Upon death of the clients, they provide legal guidance to assure appropriate settlement of the inheritance and advise individual heirs about methods to avoid claims by others.
Probate Lawyer.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 77,580 and $176,580 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $250,000.
Probate Lawyer.training: To practice law in the courts of any state, a person must be licensed or admitted to its Bar by passing an examination. To qualify for the exam, you must complete at least four years of college and graduate from an approved law school.

Real Estate Lawyer.title: Real Estate Lawyer
Real Estate Lawyer.jobTasks: Draw up documents such as deeds, mortgages and leases for the sale or transfer of properties from one party to another. Investigate property condition & value to assure validity of the transaction. They conduct title searches to ascertain if the property has any liens placed by construction subcontractors who have worked on the property. They ascertain the value of the liens. Analyze local community documents to determine if the properties violate construction codes or zoning regulations. Study survey documents to determine if the building encroaches on others. They confer with clients prior to the closing of a contract to review potential legal problems that could arise from liens, violations, or encroachments that have been discovered.
Real Estate Lawyer.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 77,580 and $176,580 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $250,000.
Real Estate Lawyer.training: To practice law in the courts of any state, a person must be licensed or admitted to its Bar by passing an examination. To qualify for the exam, you must complete at least four years of college and graduate from an approved law school.

Tax Lawyer.title: Tax Lawyer
Tax Lawyer.jobTasks: They confer with clients to determine what kinds of income and assets are taxable and what expenses and disbursements qualify as a legal deduction. They advise clients about legal exposures they have in their tax reporting procedures. They prepare opinions about tax liabilities they incurred from past transactions. They defend clients in tax litigation where a government agency claims taxes are due from the client. Study the case details, evaluate the client's earlier tax returns to prepare a defense. Advise individuals and organizations about the legal management of their estates, gifts, properties and investments. They recommend legal instruments to minimize the tax on these items.
Tax Lawyer.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 77,580 and $176,580 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $250,000.
Tax Lawyer.training: To practice law in the courts of any state, a person must be licensed or admitted to its Bar by passing an examination. To qualify for the exam, you must complete at least four years of college and graduate from an approved law school.

Border Patrol Agent.title: Border Patrol Agent
Border Patrol Agent.jobTasks: Border patrol agents detect and intercept violators of U.S. immigration laws. They pursue and arrest illegal aliens at border points and use firearms or physical force when necessary. There are over 9,000 Border Patrol Agents divided among 22 Sectors and 148 stations nationwide. These agents are dedicated to patrolling over 8,000 miles of international boundaries working around the clock on assignments, in all types of terrain and weather conditions. Border Patrol Agents utilize a variety of equipment to accomplish their job. Electronic sensors, video monitors and night vision scopes along the border detect people and vehicles attempting to enter without inspection. They use high technology communications and sensory devices. Agents patrol in 4x4 trucks, aircraft, speed boats and afoot. In some areas the agents employ horses, ATV's, mountain bikes and snowmobiles. One thing all successful Border Patrol Agents have in common is a love of the outdoors. They use techniques such as traffic stops, searching of trains, buses, trucks, aircraft, ships and passenger cargo terminals for aliens attempting to enter the country illegally. After arrests, they prepare documentation for court hearings and participate in court cases to present the government's case. They make recommendations to courts for aliens' petitions for citizenship.
Border Patrol Agent.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 55,180 and $103,330 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $131,200.
Border Patrol Agent.training: An associate degree or bachelor's degree in law enforcement or one of the social or behavioral sciences is an appropriate educational background for this occupation. Foreign language proficiency, especially Spanish is essential. A written and physical examination are required of applicants. Those hired attend an intensive 16-week Federal Government training session.

Customs Inspector.title: Customs Inspector
Customs Inspector.jobTasks: They survey persons entering the country at international entrypoints such as airports, and shipping ports in order to identify potential smugglers. May search ships, planes & trains. They examine luggage contents and person's clothing to locate smuggled goods and look for places in luggage that can serve as concealed compartments. They interview persons suspected of smuggling and ask questions designed to reveal emotions suggesting guilt. May use dogs to sniff hidden narcotics. They search, apprehend and arrest suspects and smugglers. They confiscate goods and attempt to identify all persons who act as accomplices. May testify in court.
Customs Inspector.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 55,180 and $103,330 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $131,200.
Customs Inspector.training: Customs inspectors are employed by the U.S. Treasury Department which prefers applicants with an associate degree in law enforcement or criminal justice. A college degree will improve your promotion potential. To qualify, an applicant must pass a physical examination, oral exam and a personal background investigation.

Harbor, Lake & Waterways Police.title: Harbor, Lake & Waterways Police
Harbor, Lake & Waterways Police.jobTasks: They patrol waterways in power boats in order to detect ships & boats that may be in distress and to enforce laws & regulations of the assigned waterways. Issue summons to violaters. They stop boats that are not being safely operated and check them for safety equipment and identification. They may search boats for smuggled contraband in border waterways. They perform rescue operations for boats that have capsized, have caught fire, or have been involved in an accident. They investigate the causes of accidents and issues summons. Report new navigation hazards or faulty navigation aids to Coast Guard or water safety agencies. They survey mooring buoys, docks and anchorages for compliance with laws.
Harbor, Lake & Waterways Police.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 44,000 and $ 78,140 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 98,510.
Harbor, Lake & Waterways Police.training: An associate or a bachelor's degree in criminal justice is the appropriate educational preparation for this field. To be admitted to a police training program, you generally must pass a medical and a written examination. The training program for harbor/waterway police typically consists of courses in law enforcement techniques, boat operation and patrol, safety, surveillance, raid and arrest, and use of firearms.

Immigration Inspector.title: Immigration Inspector
Immigration Inspector.jobTasks: They interview foreign persons applying for employment or residence in this country to determine their likelihood of getting a job and being able to financially support themselves. They examine the personal background and histories of the applicants to verify their education, past work experiences and financial resources. They interview persons who are willing to act as sponsors or mentors of foreign applicants, especially those applicants who only speak a foreign language. They perform follow-up investigations of those immigrants admitted into the country to assess their success in adapting to this country regarding employment, law abidance and education.
Immigration Inspector.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 55,180 and $103,330 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $131,200.
Immigration Inspector.training: An associate degree in one of the social or behavioral sciences, public administration or business administration is an acceptable educational background for this occupation. Specialized job training is provided to new hires by the U.S. Department of Justice Immigration Services.

Intelligence Analyst.title: Intelligence Analyst
Intelligence Analyst.jobTasks: They collect and analyze information from sources to detect plans for terrorist acts by radical groups. Sources include informers, interception of mail, hidden cameras, & audio listening devices. They infiltrate radical groups that are suspected of planning terrorist acts against civilians such as in bombings of public buildings, tunnels, bridges, airports, etc. or hi-jackings. Conduct raids on terrorists' residences or 'bomb-making plants' in order to prevent a known plan & to gather evidence needed to arrest & prosecute terrorists. May use physical & deadly force. They learn and analyze customs and languages of ethnic groups suspected of terrorism to interpret their behaviors & spoken words. They search for 'hidden codes' in their communications.
Intelligence Analyst.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 55,180 and $103,330 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $131,200.
Intelligence Analyst.training: Typically, a Bachelorâ€™s Degree from a 4-year college (some are 5 years) is required to be considered for this occupation.

Intelligence Specialist.title: Intelligence Specialist
Intelligence Specialist.jobTasks: They analyze and interpret reports prepared by spies and informers about plans and strength of hostile and aggressive countries or groups within a country. They study satellite photographs of territories that potentially aggressive forces have settled to estimate the type & number of weapons they possess and the presence of modern missiles and planes. They advise military and government intelligence executives about the need for further information about particular nations or hostile groups. They study reports and photographs of civilian factories and laboratories that have the potential to produce missiles, bacteriological weapons, gases and nuclear weapons.
Intelligence Specialist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 55,180 and $103,330 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $131,200.
Intelligence Specialist.training: Intelligence specialists are employees of the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation. Applicants for this position should have a 4-year college degree, preferably in the criminal justice field, pass a written examination and graduate from a special training program for agents.

Narcotics Investigator.title: Narcotics Investigator
Narcotics Investigator.jobTasks: They conduct surveillance of persons suspected of illegal dealings in narcotics. They use videotaping, wiretapping and audiotaping of conversations that could prove guilt. They analyze patterns of narcotic sales to identify sources and methods of drug traffic. They concentrate on arrests of regional distributors and identify ports of entry of narcotics. They pose as drug dealers in order to infiltrate narcotic rings. They attempt to legally entrap drug dealers by setting up transactions witnessed by government agents. Build up a network of informers willing to warn the investigator about large narcotic shipments. They test the composition of confiscated drugs to diagnose the source and potential hazards.
Narcotics Investigator.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 55,180 and $103,330 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $131,200.
Narcotics Investigator.training: Narcotics investigators or drug enforcement special agents are employees of the U.S. Department of Justice or the U.S. Treasury Department of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms (ATF). The positions require a college degree preferably in the criminal justice field. Applicants must pass a written examination and graduate from a special training program for agents.

Parole Officer.title: Parole Officer
Parole Officer.jobTasks: They assess the educational, psychological and job skill strength of a prisoner paroled from prison in order to determine the parolee's employability. Provide career and educational counseling to the parolee to help them secure employment and security. They contact employees to help place the parolee in a job. Survey and analyze the parolee's social and job behavior to assure the parolee is not regressing back to criminal behaviors. They talk to parolee's employer and social contacts to verify good behaviors. They advise legal authorities about violations of parole rules by the the parolee. They make recommendations and judgments about the parolee's chances of rehabilitation.
Parole Officer.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 39,530 and $ 67,420 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 88,930.
Parole Officer.training: The usual educational requirement is a bachelor's degree in study areas that combine social service work, counseling and law enforcement. A master's degree is helpful for the best positions and for advancement in state parole and federal probation agencies. In most parole agencies, appointees are required to participate in a training program covering basic law, firearms, social work, case management and arrest procedures.

Police and Detectives Supervisor.title: Police and Detectives Supervisor
Police and Detectives Supervisor.jobTasks: Supervise and coordinate the investigation of criminal cases, offering guidance and expertise to investigators, and ensuring that procedures are conducted in accordance with laws and regulations. Maintain logs, prepare reports, and direct the preparation, handling, and maintenance of departmental records. Explain police operations to subordinates to assist them in performing their job duties. Cooperate with court personnel and officials from other law enforcement agencies and testify in court as necessary. Review contents of written orders to ensure adherence to legal requirements. Investigate and resolve personnel problems within organization and charges of misconduct against staff. Direct collection, preparation, and handling of evidence and personal property of prisoners. Inform personnel of changes in regulations and policies, implications of new or amended laws, and new techniques of police work. Train staff in proper police work procedures. Monitor and evaluate the job performance of subordinates, and authorize promotions and transfers.
Police and Detectives Supervisor.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 64,870 and $107,660 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $134,810.
Police and Detectives Supervisor.training: The typical training required for this career is generally a High School Degree or GED Certificate.

Police Artist.title: Police Artist
Police Artist.jobTasks: They interview victims and witnesses of a crime to determine the characteristics of the suspects and the scenes where a crime took place. They start to sketch during the interview process. They encourage the victim or witness to actively critique the drawings to make them more accurate through comments about facial or body proportions, coloring, blemishes and facial expressions. May use a computer to display to witnesses different shapes of various parts of the face such as eyes, the brow, nose and lips in order to piece together the parts that best depict suspects. They draw schematics of crime scenes that are used in court trials to explain to the jury how a crime was committed and how the clues point to the suspects.
Police Artist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 32,230 and $ 72,260 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $103,680.
Police Artist.training: An associate degree or a bachelor's degree in fine arts from a college or an accredited school of art is the usual required training for a police artist. Coursework in studio arts and visual communication are essential. A knowledge of computer applications in art and design is necessary. Applicants should assemble a 'portfolio' containing examples of their best artwork to show to prospective employers.

Police Detective.title: Police Detective
Police Detective.jobTasks: They examine scenes of crimes to identify materials and objects which can link suspects to the crime. Rationally hypothesize motivation for the crimes to narrow down suspect list. They interrogate suspects to determine the probability that they could have committed the crime. Investigate the accuracy of their statements by checking with other persons. They advise suspects about their rights during the investigation procedures. May place suspects under arrest if the evidence is convincing and they may videotape voluntary confessions. May use police artists and expertise of professionals such as chemists, pathologists and ballistic experts to build a case against a suspect. Testify in court trials to present facts.
Police Detective.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 55,180 and $103,330 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $131,200.
Police Detective.training: An increasing number of cities and states require candidates for detective positions to have a bachelor's degree or at least an associate degree in law enforcement or criminal justice. Detective positions in federal agencies such as the FBI or Treasury Department require a bachelor's degree. Written and physical examinations are required.

Police Identification and Records Office.title: Police Identification and Records Officers
Police Identification and Records Office.jobTasks: Collect evidence at crime scene, classify and identify fingerprints, and photograph evidence for use in criminal and civil cases.
Police Identification and Records Office.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 55,180 and $103,330 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $131,200.
Police Identification and Records Office.training: Training for this occupation generally requires an Associate Degree from a 2 year or community college.

Police Officer.title: Police Officer
Police Officer.jobTasks: They patrol assigned territories with patrol cars, motorcycles or on foot to interact with community residents. They monitor vehicles and pedestrians to detect and investigate unusual activities. They meet with neighborhood leaders to win their cooperation in reducing crime rates. They conduct crime reduction training sessions for parents and leaders. Give public recognition. Control both motor vehicle traffic & pedestrian traffic during peak periods. Investigate causes of accidents and administers first aid to injured persons. They issue summons to violators. They act as a mediator to defuse conflict between individuals or groups as a means of preventing violence. They use crowd control methods on horseback or attack dogs during protests & riots.
Police Officer.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 44,000 and $ 78,140 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 98,510.
Police Officer.training: An increasing number of cities and states require applicants to have either an associate degree or bachelor's degree in law enforcement, criminal justice or justice administration. Written and physical examinations are required. Knowledge of a foreign languages is an asset. Police officers usually receive formal training in constitutional law and civil rights, state law and local ordinance and accident investigation.

Security and Fire Alarm Systems Installe.title: Security and Fire Alarm Systems Installers
Security and Fire Alarm Systems Installe.jobTasks: Install, program, maintain, and repair security and fire alarm wiring and equipment. Ensure that work is in accordance with relevant codes.
Security and Fire Alarm Systems Installe.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 34,740 and $ 55,550 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 65,470.
Security and Fire Alarm Systems Installe.training: Training for this occupation generally requires a High School Degree, plus additional coursework in a vocational or technical school. In some cases, employers may require an Associate Degree.

Sheriffs.title: Sheriffs
Sheriffs.jobTasks: Enforce law and order in rural or unincorporated districts or serve legal processes of courts. May patrol courthouse, guard court or grand jury, or escort defendants.
Sheriffs.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 44,000 and $ 78,140 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 98,510.
Sheriffs.training: Training for this occupation generally requires a High School Degree, plus additional coursework in a vocational or technical school. In some cases, employers may require an Associate Degree.

Transit and Railroad Police.title: Transit and Railroad Police
Transit and Railroad Police.jobTasks: Protect and police railroad and transit property, employees, or passengers.
Transit and Railroad Police.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 54,570 and $ 81,920 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 96,670.
Transit and Railroad Police.training: The typical training required for this career is generally a High School Degree or GED Certificate.

Emergency Management Specialist.title: Emergency Management Specialist
Emergency Management Specialist.jobTasks: Keep informed of activities or changes that could affect the likelihood of an emergency, as well as those that could affect response efforts and details of plan implementation. Prepare plans that outline operating procedures to be used in response to disasters or emergencies, such as hurricanes, nuclear accidents, and terrorist attacks, and in recovery from these events. Propose alteration of emergency response procedures based on regulatory changes, technological changes, or knowledge gained from outcomes of previous emergency situations. Maintain and update all resource materials associated with emergency preparedness plans. Coordinate disaster response or crisis management activities, such as ordering evacuations, opening public shelters, and implementing special needs plans and programs.
Emergency Management Specialist.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 50,160 and $ 99,200 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $133,880.
Emergency Management Specialist.training: Typically, a Bachelorâ€™s Degree from a 4-year college (some are 5 years) is required to be considered for this occupation.

Emergency Medical Technician.title: Emergency Medical Technician
Emergency Medical Technician.jobTasks:
They diagnose the extent of injured persons' wounds or ill person's problems by measuring and observing their vital signs such as blood pressure, pulse, temperature and pain.
Apply bandages and tourniquets to stop bleeding, administer pain relievers and antiseptics to prevent infections, and apply splints to broken bones.
They may have to use cardio-pulmonary resuscitation (CPR) methods to revive persons in cases of drownings, heart attacks, choking or other life-threatening situations.
They drive emergency vehicles such as an ambulance. They monitor the patient's condition during the trip and receive instructions via radio from physicians during the trip.
Emergency Medical Technician.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 25,850 and $ 42,710 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 56,310.
Emergency Medical Technician.training: It is important to have an associate degree in some branch of health science, although it is not a requirement. Formal training is needed to become an emergency medical technician, consisting of 100 to 120 hours of classroom work plus 10 hours of internship in a hospital emergency room. The training is available through community agencies, hospitals, and as a non-degree course in colleges and universities. Certification is required and achieved by passing a written and practical examination.

Fire Inspector.title: Fire Inspector
Fire Inspector.jobTasks:
They examine building structures, materials used for construction, electrical systems, heating and cooking equipment, etc., to determine if fire hazards are present.
They determine if fire detection and alarm systems are adequate. They issue legal warnings to building owners to eliminate fire hazards and make recommendations for punishment of violators.
They perform tests to determine if specific construction materials meet requirements for fire resistance and how they should be modified to make them acceptable.
Issue permits for use of buildings that satisfy fire resistance codes. They examine buildings that have burned to diagnose the cause of the fire. Investigate potential arson cases.
Fire Inspector.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 44,090 and $ 76,480 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 95,270.
Fire Inspector.training: An associate degree in construction engineering or architecture is the usual educational background required by city, state and Federal government employers of fire inspectors. Courses in construction, materials science and blueprint reading are important. Government agencies usually require that you pass a civil service examination.

Fire Investigator.title: Fire Investigator
Fire Investigator.jobTasks: Package collected pieces of evidence in securely closed containers such as bags, crates, or boxes, to protect them. Examine fire sites and collect evidence such as glass, metal fragments, charred wood, and accelerant residue for use in determining the cause of a fire. Instruct children about the dangers of fire. Analyze evidence and other information to determine probable cause of fire or explosion. Photograph damage and evidence related to causes of fires or explosions to document investigation findings. Subpoena and interview witnesses, property owners, and building occupants to obtain information and sworn testimony. Swear out warrants, and arrest and process suspected arsonists. Testify in court cases involving fires, suspected arson, and false alarms. Prepare and maintain reports of investigation results, and records of convicted arsonists and arson suspects. Test sites and materials to establish facts, such as burn patterns and flash points of materials, using test equipment. back to top
Fire Investigator.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 44,090 and $ 76,480 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $ 95,270.
Fire Investigator.training: Typically, a Bachelorâ€™s Degree from a 4-year college (some are 5 years) is required to be considered for this occupation.

Fire Prevention Engineer.title: Fire Prevention Engineer
Fire Prevention Engineer.jobTasks:
They determine what building construction materials and equipment should be used to assure fire resistant structures.
They perform technical experiments and studies to assess fire resistance properties of specific construction materials. They specify how to treat materials to make them more fire resistant.
Recommend what kinds of fire detection and alarm systems are needed to protect different types of dwellings, commercial buildings, factories, hotels, etc.
Design fire sprinkler systems for buildings that are triggered when fire detection systems sense fire caused fumes, smoke or heat.
Fire Prevention Engineer.earningsDetails: People established in their career generally earn between $ 65,490 and $110,760 per year. Exceptional performers can earn in excess of $134,110.
Fire Prevention Engineer.training: A bachelor's degree from an accredited engineering program with a concentration in materials science and construction engineering is the usual requirement for this occupation. Most states require certification by passing a written examination.

Firefighter.title: Firefighter
Firefighter.jobTasks:
They analyze severity, kinds of materials burning and path of fire to decide best methods, equipment and chemicals that should be used to fight a fire.
They determine if any persons are trapped in the fire and the potential threat that the fire will harm spectators or nearby residents by explosions or gases.
They protect surrounding buildings, fields, woods or materials from the fire by wetting or dousing them with water or fire retarding chemicals.
They administer first-aid to burn victims or those suffering from smoke inhalation. They inspect and maintain fire fighting apparatus, drive fire trucks, ambulances and fire-boats.
